pages.subdeck: Madness ... cop closes Dorset fuel station yesterday amid panic-buying chaos
pages.headline: Total panic
pages.teaser: OFFICERS in Dorset shut a Total garage plus six others as fights erupt among drivers
pages.byline: By KEVIN SCHOFIELD, NICK PARKER and STEVE HAWKES
pages.articlebody:
POLICE closed petrol stations amid panic-buying chaos yesterday  after ANOTHER clanger by the Government.

Officers in Dorset temporarily shut a Total garage plus six others as fights erupted among drivers queuing to beat the threatened tanker strike.

Hundreds more were forced to close nationwide after David Cameron's Energy Secretary Ed Davey advised keeping petrol tanks two-thirds full.

Early today Tories slumped in the Bradford West by-election as voters gave the thumbs down to the Budget and their handling of the fuel crisis.

Last night drivers were urged to stop panic-buying  because tanker drivers will not strike this side of Easter.

Talks about avoiding a stoppage start on Monday, with unions needing to give seven days notice of a walkout.

So even if negotiations break down it means no strike until after Easter Monday  although union bosses ARE still holding the country to ransom.

The AA called for calm after more chaos on forecourts yesterday following the Government's bungling advice for motorists to fill jerry cans with fuel.

AA president Edmund King said: "There is no strike and therefore if drivers followed normal fuel-buying patterns there would be no fuel shortage whatsoever.

"We now have self-inflicted shortages due to poor advice about topping up the tank and hoarding in jerry cans."

The Petrol Retailers Association  which represents 5,500 garages  added: "The Government was entirely responsible for the chaos.

"They were irresponsible and started people panic-buying.

"They don't know if there's going to be a strike so if people carry on as normal it will be fine."

"Our message is: Please don't panic buy. It's not helping."

The message was still not getting through yesterday  with hundreds of petrol stations forced to close as motorists drained them dry.

Some queued for more than an hour to reach a pump  amid reports of fights between drivers.

Police shut some garages for fear of accidents as queuing drivers spilled on to busy roads.

Petrol sales have soared 81 per cent and diesel 43 per cent since the crisis began.

Sales of jerry cans  which Cabinet Secretary Francis Maude urged motorists to fill  have rocketed by 500 per cent.

In Dorset yesterday there were long queues from dawn. By mid-morning garages in Weymouth and Christchurch had run dry  with some having sold three days worth of fuel in a few hours. Jason Babbe, 33, queued for an hour.

He said: "I saw an argument between a taxi driver and another motorist and other rows going on."

"As well as filling up their tanks people were filling up cans."

An attendant at Texaco in Weymouth said: "People are going mad. We've sold what we'd normally sell in three days in hours."

In Devon, staff at Sainsbury's Alphington store had to shepherd cars into lines after claims of queue-jumping caused outrage.

Charlie Bell said: "Traffic is coming in from both directions. I am empty  but I wonder how many people are following the daft advice to keep topped up?"

In Wilmslow, Cheshire, there were claims of profiteering as one petrol station hiked its diesel price to 148.9p a litre.

Mum Fiona Barrett, 56, said: "It seems extraordinary there can be diesel on sale at two stations half a mile apart with a 5p difference."

In Chelsea, West London, firemen had to clean up a diesel spill when a van driver trying to cram as much in his tank as possible sent fuel spilling across a forecourt.

At Morrisons in Dukinfield, near Manchester, tempers boiled over  with one motorist yelling four-letter abuse at those queuing. One 70-year-old great grandma caught in a tailback said: "The Government has a lot to answer for."

The AA yesterday said drivers queuing for pumps were actually wasting fuel. Waiting with an engine idling costs up to 3p a minute  so queuing for 45 minutes wastes around a litre of fuel.

Yesterday the Government continued to send out confused messages.

Transport minister Mike Penning said: "Don't queue  but if you've got half a tank, fill it up."

But Lib Dem Energy Secretary Ed Davey advised people to "fill up when they can"  and aim to keep tanks two thirds full. On Tuesday the Government advised us all to fill our tanks.

Then on Wednesday Mr Maude suggested drivers should also have a jerry can of fuel in their garage.

His advice was described as dangerous and illegal by fire chiefs.

The strike is being threatened by about 2,000 tanker drivers over pay and safety concerns.

Talks between the Unite union and the seven employers in the dispute take place at the conciliation service Acas on Monday. Unite said: "We want a negotiated settlement."

  • A WOMAN suffered 40 per cent burns when petrol ignited as she was transferring it to containers in her kitchen in York, North Yorkshire Fire and Rescue Service said.

    k.schofield@the-sun.co.uk



    Fuel set to rise again

    BRITAIN'S panicked drivers were last night told that petrol prices are going even HIGHER.

    Motoring chiefs warned that wholesale prices on international markets had soared to a new record. This means pump prices are almost certain to rise by 2p per litre in the next ten days.

    With the extra 2p, diesel will be averaging almost 150p per litre  nearly £7 a gallon.

    Official figures show motorists bought 3.1bn fewer litres last year compared to 2007. Diesel sales are up slightly, but petrol has plunged.

    AA president Edmund King said: "Some people are being priced out of fuel. People feel they just cannot afford to fill up. That's the irony of the Government saying, 'Fill up'  many can't."



    Risk facing a judge and jerry

    MOTORISTS could unwittingly end up breaking the law if they decide to store petrol in jerry cans.

    Many websites and stores, including Amazon and Halfords, are selling 20-litre metal cans for under £30.

    But it is illegal to have more than ten litres in one container. The maximum allowed at home is 20 litres.



    Walkouts hit Easter

    HOLIDAYMAKERS face Easter chaos after baggage handlers at Stansted Airport last night voted to strike.

    The walkout on Good Friday, Easter Saturday and Bank Holiday Monday will hit travel at one of the airport's busiest times.

    More than 150 staff are furious at shift changes by employer Swissport, which workers say will lead to pay cuts of up to £1,000.

    The GMB union said the action would go ahead unless a settlement was agreed.

    Tory co-chairman Baroness Warsi called on Labour leader Ed Miliband to condemn the strike. She said: "His union paymasters seem hell-bent on ruining Easter for hard-working families." Ryanair plans to bypass the strike by making flights "carry-on baggage only".

article.caption: Petrol panic to raise £32m extra fuel duty
Half-baked
'Scab' jibe at troops

pages.subdeck: Alien invasion fantasy ... Rihanna, star of new film Battleship, scoured the skies for UFOs
pages.headline: Rihanna: My alien obsession
pages.teaser: EXCLUSIVE: BAJAN superstar reveals she scoured the skies for UFOs on orders of her dad
pages.articlebody:
RIHANNA has revealed she spent much of her childhood gazing up into the skies for signs of an alien invasion.

As a kid in Bridgetown, Barbados, she would spend hours sitting on her porch, watching for UFOs  on the orders of her dad Ronald Fenty.

He was convinced that aliens were going to visit earth and the singer says: "My dad used to make me sit outside on the steps all night long looking for UFOs flying by, and I had to do that for years.

"I didn't see any but I saw a falling star once and I was like, 'Yessss, Dad! Come and see, it just darted.' "

In less than a fortnight the singer's fans will be able to see Rihanna experiencing her closest encounter yet with aliens  in her big-screen debut in the sci-fi blockbuster Battleship.

The 12A movie, which also features Liam Neeson and rising star Taylor Kitsch, opens on April 11.

In it Rihanna plays an American navy gunner called Raikes, who takes on some scary-looking aliens.

After releasing six albums in just five years, winning five Grammys and scoring numerous hits with such songs as Umbrella and Only Girl (In the World), Rihanna has taken the leap into acting in her stride.

She claims she had been looking for the right part for a while  so perhaps it was her early interest in aliens which sealed the deal for her first major role.

The film tells the tale of a US naval crew's confrontation with aliens who are protected by minders called "thugs".

Speaking at a London hotel, the 24-year-old singer recalls the moment she went to meet the film's director, Peter Berg, for the first time.

She says: "I didn't know much about the part and I didn't even know about the meeting I was supposed to be going into.

"Pete walked right in and said, 'These are the thugs' and he was pointing to these alien characters and showing demos of them.

"There were tons of pictures of them on the wall. Every time he said it was a thug I was cracking up.

"Not until the end of the meeting did I realise he was the director of the film and what the film was about.

"He told me to say, 'I am going to get you, mother******' and he had me saying the craziest stuff right on the spot and he said, 'Yeah, I think you are perfect.' "

However Rihanna quickly discovered she was less than "perfect" for a military screen role.

To prepare for the part, she hired a soldier to help with her fitness training.

And the Bajan beauty, who is known for her love of fashion and partying, soon discovered it did not fit in with her lifestyle.

She says: "The soldier was definitely scary, scary, scary. It was intense but necessary.

"I didn't think of quitting on the film, but every minute of the training I was thinking of quitting. I was like, 'I need to get this guy out of my hotel room.'

"When he came round I would hide my pink iPod and my high heels.

"I felt guilty shopping when I was making this film."

As The Sun revealed last month, Rihanna had an early taste of army-style discipline in her youth as a member of the Barbados Cadet Corps.

She recalls: "I didn't want to be at school for schoolwork, that was boring.

"I wanted to join an organisation and everything else was kind of not my thing, so I joined the cadets. They had weapons."

Today the wild-living star has a lot of respect for armed forces and the sacrifices they make.

Even if she hadn't become famous, Rihanna doubts that she could have served her country.

She says: "A soldier? I don't know. That is, I mean, if I had to I definitely would  I have so much respect for soldiers.

"They dedicate their lives to saving other lives and saving their countries and a lot of times they don't even get recognised for it, even when they come back. Sometimes they don't have a place to go.

"It's really sad but they put themselves on the line out there and I admire them so, so much.

"It really takes a certain character and person with a certain discipline to be a soldier."

Rihanna continues: "In the movie my character is named Raikes and she's a bad-ass. She's really tough and she's one of the boys."

As to whether she enjoyed being a "bad-ass" she jokes: "Definitely. It's like my everyday life."

However, the regular routine of the film set was far from Rihanna's everyday life.

That usually involves jetting round the world  whereas staying put on location in Hawaii was very different.

She says: "I'm used to getting on a plane every day or being in a different time zone every day.

"But on a film set you are just in one place for a long time. You start and end work every day at the same time."

Despite the rigid routine Rihanna admits she was not well prepared for her first day of filming.

She says: "The fear of the unknown is incredible. I didn't know what I was getting into.

"It was really scary and there was little me, just trying to get through everything, hoping they wouldn't come for me today.

"And then on the very first day it was 'Boom,' you are up and you have got lines."

The film was inspired by the popular children's game Battleships  though its popularity clearly has not spread to Rihanna's household.

She says: "Actually, I didn't even know of the game, because in Barbados it doesn't even exist."

Luckily fans of her music need not worry that she is about to swap careers permanently.

She has every intention of getting back into the recording studio and says: "Doing movies and getting into acting is something that I always wanted to try and I never knew whether I would like it, hate it or love it but I just wanted to try it.

"It ended up being a really awesome experience. But I don't see why I can't do both acting and music."

g.rollings@the-sun.co.uk

pages.subdeck: George Osborne ... with pasty
pages.headline: The pied paupers
pages.teaser: THE tax helps George Osborne take more cash from ordinary Brits than he is giving them, The Sun can reveal
pages.byline: By TOM NEWTON DUNN, Political Editor
pages.articlebody:
THE Pasty Tax is helping George Osborne to take more cash from millions of ordinary Brits than he is giving them, The Sun can reveal.

The Chancellor trumpeted last week's Budget as a boost for hard-pressed pockets because he raised the income tax threshold.

But a Sun analysis of official Treasury figures we have seen tells a different story. And it shows an average hard-working Sun reader earning £19,000 a year will be £21.52 WORSE OFF.

Once inflation is stripped away, he or she gains £170 a year by paying less income tax. But because Mr Osborne failed to halt a fuel duty rise, slapped 20 per cent VAT on hot pies and pasties and hiked the levy on cigs by 37p a packet, they will be £191.52 poorer.

This is based on a reader eating a medium pasty every other working day, smoking ten cigs a day and driving 7,000 miles in a Ford Focus.

Self-employed workers who need vans will lose much more.

Join the nation's crusade against the Pasty Tax by signing the petition below...

The TaxPayers' Alliance said our analysis proved Mr Osborne had "pulled a fast one by giving with one hand, taking with the other".

Campaign director Emma Boon added: "Those who enjoy simple pleasures will take an almighty hit."

The botched Budget  in which the income tax rate for top earners was cut  continued to provoke fury yesterday. And even senior Tories were worried Mr Osborne and Prime Minister David Cameron are looking increasingly out of touch with the public.

Ex-leadership challenger David Davis warned the party's "rich toff" image could be as damaging to the Government as the sleaze scandals that battered John Major's administration.

Mr Davis, who grew up on a council estate, said: "People look at the front bench and they see them all well-dressed, well turned out, well fed. And perhaps feel they're in a different world to them." Another of Mr Osborne's arguments for the Pasty Tax crumbled yesterday. He claimed he was closing a loophole left when ex-Chancellor Nigel Lawson put VAT on takeaway grub in 1984.

But a letter that emerged yesterday, written by Lord Lawson at the time, said: "It does not apply to things like pies and pastries sold warm because they happen to be freshly baked."

Mr Cameron's red face over his pasty blunder grew even redder yesterday. On Wednesday it emerged a shop at Leeds railway station, where he said he had enjoyed his last pasty, closed four years ago.

In a bid to correct the gaffe, a No10 spin doctor later said the PM actually bought it in Liverpool. But the claim was withdrawn yesterday after Mr Cameron said it was wrong. An aide said: "There was no intention to mislead. He definitely bought a pasty recently on a trip out of London."

t.newtondunn@the-sun.co.uk



At Westminster it's a roll tax riot

AN army of angry Brits waved pasties in protest at George Osborne's daft tax yesterday.

Hundreds demonstrated outside Parliament amid growing disgust from within the Coalition. Dan Rogerson, Lib Dem MP for North Cornwall, home of the pasty, said: "It has the potential to really hit the industry." Locals in Looe defiantly scoffed their county's dish yesterday while Sun readers claimed free sausage rolls at Morrisons stores.

Parliament Square protester Beth Crawley, 24, said: "I eat a pasty a day, they're my favourite. We need the country to come together." Our Who VAT All The Pies? campaign won support from as far away as Canada, Australia and Brazil. Celebs including pop star Olly Murs, Towie's Kirk Norcross and Big Brother's Georgia Salpa joined the fight while comic Al Murray tweeted: "Smash the pasty tax."



myView

By ALEX JAMES, Sun Foodie

IN FRANCE they have charcuterie. Italy has its air-dried hams and Germany's got the wurst.

Every nation has a different way of transforming pork into something they are very proud of.

But our hot sausage roll is the jewel in the crown  a British institution. They come in all shapes and sizes and you don't find them anywhere else.

Pasties are equally delicious. Service station ones are not the best but I still succumb to the odd cheese and onion in moments of weakness.

At the other end of the gastro scale, the European Commission recently granted Cornish pasties the same status and protection as champagne  meaning only those made in Cornwall following the traditional recipe can be called a "Cornish pasty".

These were the original British packed lunch for tin miners. The crust was a kind of handle. The men had dirty hands so would throw it away once they'd eaten the rest.

Both of these foods date from when people did more physical work and burned more calories.

And I can't help feeling this VAT on hot sausage rolls and pasties might really be some kind of stealth fat tax.



Sign up to battle

THE Sun is teaming up with pie shops and pasty makers across Britain today for a "March of the Bakers".

We are joining forces with Greggs and the National Association of Master Bakers to urge the Chancellor to dump his hated Pasty Tax.

Petitions will be in each of Greggs's 1,500 stores. Chief executive Ken McMeikan wants the House of Commons to force ministers into a U-turn.

The NAMB has already launched an e-petition. You can sign it by clicking on the link above.

pages.subdeck: SPEAK NO EVIL ... Alex Ferguson says Patrick Vieira should not be talking about officials
pages.headline: Gag Pat
pages.teaser: MAN UTD boss suggests Vieira could face action over referee bias allegations
pages.articlebody:
ALEX FERGUSON cranked up the title mind games last night by suggesting Patrick Vieira could face an FA charge.

The Old Trafford boss was reacting angrily to the Frenchman's allegations that Manchester United get favours from referees.

He pointed out that Vieira, as an employee of Manchester City, could potentially risk an FA rap for daring to question referees' professionalism.

Ferguson said: "He's more or less saying all the refs have been wrong this season and you're not supposed to discuss referees. He is a paid official isn't he?"

Vieira is employed as City's football development executive.

The latest squabble comes after Vieira sparked an angry response from Old Trafford earlier for claiming Paul Scholes' comeback from retirement was a sign of weakness.

Then on Wednesday, he stated: "When United play at home they get some advantage that other teams don't get.

"I think when you go to United, Madrid, Barcelona or Milan, when the referees referee these kind of games it's always difficult to go against these kind of teams. This is the way it is."

Vieira's comments came after Fulham were denied a last-gasp penalty at Old Trafford last Monday that could have cost United two points in their title battle with City.

Yet Ferguson claimed United get the rough end of lots of decisions and it is City who have been lucky.

He added: "Manchester City could have had a penalty given against them at Stoke, as everyone saw with Gareth Barry.

"Somebody said a few years ago that Manchester United always get penalty kicks at Old Trafford.

"But when you go through the statistics since I have been here, it only averages out at three a year.

"You cannot say that is a lot for an attacking team like ourselves."

Ferguson joked that if Vieira was missing being fully involved in title tussles with United, he could help out.

He quipped: "I can bring Keane back if he wants, make it interesting!"

The FA have deemed Vieira's comments not serious enough or specific in their nature for action to be taken on this occasion.

article.caption: City ruled for three months, that's hardly a season

pages.subdeck: A bit of all white ... Abbey Clancy paddles in the water
pages.headline: Abbey is every inch a beauty
pages.teaser: MODEL's daughter looks set to be as tall as famous mum
pages.byline: By EMILY NASH and DAN SALES
pages.articlebody:
ABBEY Clancy is every inch a beauty as she paddles in the sea on a sunshine break.

And daughter Sophia Ruby looks set to reach the same heights as her model mum and beanpole 6ft 7ins footie ace dad Peter Crouch.

The one-year-old, who playfully tried on her mum's sunhat as they cuddled on the beach, already looks big for her age.

And if she keeps growing at the same rate she could be taller than her 5ft 9ins mum by the age of 20, experts say.

The Sun revealed last August how the toddler was 2ft 4ins at just five months old  as tall as many kids twice her age.

Now, just two weeks after her first birthday, she is already around 3ft.

Jill Irving of BabyCentre said: "If she grows as fast as she has been, she'll be edging towards six foot.

"At the age of 20, according to the World Health Organisation growth charts, she will be 5ft 10ins. She's going to be a tall girl."

Abbey, 26, and Sophia Ruby are enjoying a break at the luxury Grosvenor House Hotel in Dubai while Stoke City striker Crouch prepares to play Wigan tomorrow.

e.nash@the-sun.co.uk

nibs.headline: 150 cops work on hacking inquiry
nibs.teaser: LONDON'S Deputy Mayor also revealed £40m probe bill
nibs.articlebody:
THE Met Police has 150 cops working on the phone hacking investigation and just 27 devoted to nailing paedophiles, London's Deputy Mayor said yesterday.

Kit Malthouse  who has special responsibility for policing and crime  told the Leveson Inquiry into Press standards the number probing hacking would rise to 200 next year.

It is equivalent to eight murder squads. Mr Malthouse also revealed the forecast for spending on the Operation Weeting inquiry and related investigations is £40million.

In contrast, he said, £36million was spent annually on investigating child abuse in London.

Mr Malthouse said that in 2009 Scotland Yard had a backlog of 400 rape cases and when Weeting began in early 2011 it was clear it would be a "large drain on resources".

He told the inquiry: "I was keen to ensure they were not undertaking this investigation at the detriment of, for instance, rape victims. Having sat and watched the tears roll down the faces of rape victims as they recounted what happened I was acutely aware of that problem."

Linda Bowman, mum of murdered 18-year-old Sally Anne, said she was surprised by the figures.

Linda, 49, of Croydon, South London, said: "There were wrongs at the News of the World, but children should come first. Anyone who harms a hair on a child's head should be locked up for life."

Scotland Yard said although there were 27 officers in its Paedophile Unit, there were 470 on the Child Abuse Investigation Command.

- SCOTLAND Yard communications chief Dick Fedorcio quit yesterday. He faced misconduct allegations over the decision to hire ex-News of the World executive Neil Wallis as a PR adviser.

c.grant@the-sun.co.uk

image.caption: Boss ... Kit Malthouse

nibs.headline: Cowell takes on Xtras
nibs.teaser: DEAL brokered by The Sun after mogul clashed with the Work and Pensions Secretary
nibs.byline: By GRAEME WILSON, Deputy Political Editor
nibs.articlebody:
SIMON Cowell will give jobless kids work experience on the X Factor in a deal with ministers brokered by The Sun.

The show's boss made the offer after Work and Pensions Secretary Iain Duncan Smith urged him to give unemployed teens a chance.

The minister wrote to Cowell following the pair's clash in The Sun. The music mogul has sent back a letter declaring he is eager to help out.

A source said: "Much of what Simon does is giving opportunities to talented people  this applies to his company as well as the TV shows."

Cowell has told executives at his company Syco Entertainment to meet with government officials.

Syco has 35 staff in the UK  including five who joined after work experience. He already helps 10 youngsters who are currently on experience.

A Syco insider said: "Simon likes people who want to learn and work hard."

Earlier this month Mr Duncan Smith said the X Factor gave false hope. Cowell told The Sun the minister was talking rubbish.

g.wilson@the-sun.co.uk

nibs.headline: Damian Lewis is set to guest host Have I Got News For You
nibs.teaser: ACCLAIMED Homeland actor will take the reins at the BBC1 topical show for the fourth time
nibs.articlebody:
HOMELAND star Damian Lewis is set to guest host Have I Got News For You for one episode.

The actor will be taking over the reins for a fourth time on the BBC1 topical show, with Ian Hislop and Paul Merton returning as regular captains.

Former Labour spin doctor Alastair Campbell will be making his debut in episode eight.

Dirk Gently star Stephen Mangan will have his third stint in the chair, joined by actor and comedian Miles Jupp, known for his role in TV show Rev.

Top Gear presenter and Sun columnist Jeremy Clarkson, radio presenter Jo Brand and comic Alexander Armstrong, who is appearing for a record-breaking 20th time, will also be taking to the stage in the 43rd series.

Have I Got News For You begins again on BBC1 at 9pm from April 13.

pages.subdeck: 'Thanks for support' ... Fabrice Muamba smiles as he sits up in hospital
pages.headline: First picture of Fabrice Muamba since heart attack
pages.teaser: THE first picture of a smiling Fabrice Muamba has been posted on the stricken footie ace's Twitter page.
pages.articlebody:
THE first picture of Fabrice Muamba since his heart attack has been posted on the footie ace's Twitter page.

The star, who suffered a heart attack 13 days ago in an FA Cup tie, is pictured sitting up in hospital smiling.

The amazing picture shows how far the Bolton star's recovery has gone after doctors said he was "technically dead" for 78 minutes.

The message, thought to be from his fiancee Shauna Magunda, said: "Fab wanted me to post this pic for you all and to also say thank you for such overwhelming support."

More to follow

pages.subdeck: Unfit to be tried ... Shrien Dewani
pages.headline: Dewani extradition halted on mental health grounds
pages.teaser: JUDGES rule honeymoon murder suspect's extradition is 'unjust and oppressive'
pages.articlebody:
HONEYMOON murder suspect Shrien Dewani's extradition to South Africa has been temporarily halted on mental health grounds.

Two High Court judges in London ruled it would be "unjust and oppressive" to order the removal of Dewani, who is accused of arranging the contract killing of wife Anni in Cape Town in November 2010.

But they said it was plainly in the interests of justice that he should be extradited "as soon as he is fit" to be tried.

Care home owner Dewani, from Bristol, denies any wrongdoing.

He has been diagnosed with post-traumatic stress disorder and depression and his lawyers argue that his health and life will be at risk if he is extradited.

The Dewani family welcomed the ruling, saying: "Shrien can only return to South Africa when he is well enough and when his personal safety can be guaranteed."

Anni's sister Ami Denborg said her family "just want him to get better now so he can finally go to South Africa and tell us what happened".

She added: "I feel, and we feel, that there are a lot of delays and it is very painful for us, but we want to get to the truth about what happened to our sister Anni.

"We just want to know the truth because it is all about our dearest little sister who was murdered."

Sir John Thomas, president of the Queen's Bench Division, and Mr Justice Ouseley allowed Dewani's appeal against immediate extradition.

The judges said they believed he was unfit to plead, and cited a "lack of clear certainty" about what would happen if he was returned to South Africa in his present condition.

Anni, 28, from Sweden, was shot when a taxi the couple were travelling in was hijacked in the Gugulethu township on the outskirts of Cape Town.

She was found dead in the back of the abandoned vehicle with a bullet wound to her neck after taxi driver Zola Tongo drove the newlyweds to the impoverished area.

He and Dewani were ejected by the hijackers before Anni was driven away and shot.

Tongo, who admitted his part in the crime, claimed in a plea agreement with prosecutors that Dewani ordered the carjacking and paid for a hit on his wife.

In their statement, the businessman's family said: "The Dewani family are grateful that the High Court has upheld the appeal and blocked any attempt to extradite Shrien to South Africa now.

"Shrien is innocent and is determined to return to South Africa to clear his name and seek justice for his wife Anni.

"The High Court has confirmed that extradition now would be 'unjust and oppressive'. The matter is still before the courts and so it would be inappropriate to comment further."

image.caption: Unfit to be tried ... Shrien Dewani

pages.subdeck: Delighted ... Robbie and Ayda
pages.headline: Robbie Williams to be a dad
pages.teaser: STAR says: "Me and Ayda are going to be mummy and daddy this year. We had sex! It works!"
pages.articlebody:
TAKE That star Robbie Williams has announced he is going to be a dad for the first time.

The 38-year-old singer took to his official blog this morning to reveal his wife Ayda Field is expecting.

He wrote: "I've been keeping a secret from you all... Me and Ayda are going to be mummy and daddy this year.

"We had sex! It works!"

The Angels singer admits he and his actress partner have turned into emotional wrecks while preparing for the arrival of their firstborn.

He added: "We've seen scans and cried... Looked at babies in commercials and teared up.

"The nursery is already planned. Basically I'm in love with a little person growing in mummy's belly and can't wait to be a daddy...

"Crying now. Much love much joy. Roberto, mum and little bump. XXXXXX."

image.caption: Delighted ... Robbie and Ayda

pages.subdeck: Tattoo ... poster boy David Beckham
pages.headline: Tatt's very offensive
pages.teaser: Sainsbury's apologises for provocative Posh tattoo
pages.articlebody:
SAINSBURY'S has apologised for sending publicity posters of David Beckham with a provocative tattoo of Posh Spice to 47,000 schools and community groups.

Outraged nursery staff complained to the supermarket, saying the semi-naked image of his wife was inappropriate for their children  aged two to four.

Pictures of Becks' tattoo of Victoria in lingerie on his arm appeared on promotional posters and collection boxes for the Sainsbury's Active Kids scheme.

Anita Deacon, of Winshill Pre-School in Burton, Staffordshire, said: "We're not being prudish.

"We just think it's inappropriate. The tattoo depicts Posh Spice wearing nothing but underwear and posing provocatively."

And pre-school manager Lynn Baker said: "I can see it's not really appropriate to have on show in front of children.

"We are going to keep the material in the pre-school but make sure it's too high up for the children to see."

Mark Jackson, customer manager at Sainsbury's, told school staff: "I'm sorry our recent material, which is endorsed by David Beckham, shows his tattoo of Victoria clearly semi-naked.

"I understand your disappointment, especially as this is being used in pre-schools.

"I'd like to reassure you that it's never our intention to cause offence to any of our customers and this has surely been an oversight on the part of our marketing team."

Sainsbury's said the material had been sent to 47,000 schools and community groups across Britain

The pictures appear on posters promoting a scheme providing schools with sports equipment in exchange for vouchers.

A spokesman added: "As a world-class athlete and father of four, David Beckham is the perfect ambassador for several of Sainsbury's initiatives which encourage all kids to lead healthier and more active lifestyles.

"It is never our intention to cause offence and we would like to apologise if this is the case.

"We will of course take this feedback on board when designing our Active Kids material going forward."

image.caption: Tattoo ... poster boy David Beckham

pages.subdeck: Too young to wed ... a girl of five was helped by Forced Marriage Unit last year
pages.headline: Girl of five 'is Britain's youngest forced marriage victim'
pages.teaser: YOUNGSTER is one of 400 children helped by government's Forced Marriage Unit
pages.articlebody:
A GIRL of five is believed to be Britain's youngest victim of forced marriage, figures reveal.

The youngster was one of 400 children to receive assistance from the Government's Forced Marriage Unit last year.

Amy Cumming, joint head of the unit, said 29 per cent of its cases involved minors.

She said: "The youngest of these was actually five years old, so there are children involved in the practice across the school age range."

Authorities did not reveal further details of the case or where the marriage took place to protect the girl's identity.

But child marriages are not uncommon, according to the Iranian and Kurdish Women's Rights Organisation.

The group deals with more than 100 cases of forced marriage a year.

Spokeswoman Fionnuala Murphy said: "We have had clients who are in their very early teens, 11-year-olds, 12-year-olds."

The figures were revealed as the Government considers whether to make forced marriage a crime in England, Wales and Northern Ireland.

Public consultation on the proposal will come to an end soon.

Mrs Murphy said: "Our organisation is pro-criminalisation because we believe that it will empower victims to know that this is a crime, to stand up to their parents and to stand up for their own rights and it will enable them to come forward and seek help and say, 'What's happening to me is wrong.'"

In 2011 the Forced Marriage Unit dealt with around 1,500 cases, but many more are thought to go unreported.

Forced Marriage Protection Orders were introduced in 2008 under the Forced Marriage (Civil Protection) Act 2007.

Court orders protecting an individual from forced marriage can be obtained by the police, victims or their friends.

Breaching one can attract a two-year jail term for contempt of court, but this is classed as a civil offence.

PM David Cameron wants the law to go further and ordered a public consultation on making it a criminal offence.

Last year, he said: "Forced marriage is little more than slavery. To force someone into marriage is completely wrong and I strongly believe this is a problem we should not shy away from addressing because of some cultural concerns."

A decision is expected to be announced later this year.

image.caption: Too young to wed ... a girl of five was helped by Forced Marriage Unit last year

pages.subdeck: Shhhhh...huge sign on side of house tells school kids to keep quiet
pages.headline: OAP hangs banner on his home telling schoolkids to be quiet
pages.teaser: GRUMPY pensioner living next to school has hung banner on house telling children to be quiet
pages.articlebody:
A GRUMPY pensioner living next to a school has hung a huge printed banner on his house telling children to be quiet.

Retired television presenter Graham Purches said his move was simply a polite request for the four to seven-year-olds to keep the noise down.

But his poster  which reads 'Please do not allow the children scream or shout near our home'  has angered many of the school's parents.

They say they cannot understand the objection to the sound of children at play for short periods during weekdays in termtime.

Sarah Howard-Jones, who has three children at Elmlea Infants' School, in Bristol, said she had been shocked to see the banner appear earlier this week.

She said: "I was so upset on behalf of the staff and the children. All the other parents I have spoken to feel the same."

Resident Ms Howard-Jones, 47, said that many families would love to live in a detached property close to the school in a picturesque avenue.

She said: "What could be more delightful than the sound of children playing? It is for such a limited time, especially with our climate."

The school is oversubscribed, with 273 on-time applications for 90 places last year. Only children living within 620 metres were given places.

It has recently had a £1 million revamp and tries to make the most of its grounds for the benefit of the pupils. A new safety surface has recently replaced some of the grass, enabling children to use the space in all weathers.

Mr Purches, who has lived in his home for more than 30 years, said the children's noise was sometimes so loud that he and his wife could not have a conversation in their garden.

He said the play area, which used to be 85ft from his property, was now only 10ft from his house wall.

Mr Purches said he had no objection to the school, which two of his children attended, but was asking the staff and parents to remember that they were visitors to the area and to encourage the children to respect the school's neighbours.

He said: "It is a very polite notice. The last thing we want to do it to stop children enjoying themselves. We just don't want a lot of excessive screaming and shouting."

He said he had written to the school's head teacher Inge Fey and governors several times over the years about various issues.

He had also asked Bristol City Council to install acoustic fencing but officers had replied saying that the noise level was appropriate for children aged four and five.

Catherine Ball, chairwoman of the school's governors, said: "Elmlea Infants' School is working hard to offer outstanding provision for Early Years children.

"We are very disappointed that a local resident is objecting to our children using our land which is used as much needed play space that enhances our curriculum. The play space is used during mid-morning playtime and lunchtimes which is a small part of the school day."

image.caption: Shhhhh...huge sign on side of house tells school kids to keep quiet

pages.subdeck: Brainbox ... Albert Einstein
pages.headline: Einstein proved right
pages.teaser: Boffin's complex view of the universe was correct
pages.articlebody:
BOFFINS have agreed Albert Einstein was right all along.

The genius is famed for his mind-boggling general theory of relativity in which he predicts how fast galaxies move towards each other and the rate the universe is growing.

It has taken almost 100 years and an army of cosmologists to decide his complex view of the universe was right with "incredible accuracy".

Experts announced at the National Astronomy Meeting the most accurate measurement ever made from when the expansion of the universe began to accelerate.

It means the phenomenon can be explained using Einstein's general theory of relativity and the cosmological constant  published by the brainbox in 1916.

The findings prove the university is expanding at the same speed as Einstein predicted and driven by dark energy.

Cosmologists from the University of Portsmouth and the Max Planck Institute for Extraterrestrial Physics examined the period between five and six billion years ago.

They made measurements of extraordinary accuracy  within 1.7 per cent.

Their conclusions are consistent with the concordance model of a universe that expanded from the Big Bang 13.7 million years ago.

Dr Rita Tojeiro said: "The results are the best measurement of an intergalactic distance ever made, which means cosmologists are closer than ever to understanding why the universe's expansion is accelerating.

"Einstein's theory has passed its most stringent test yet at extra-galactic scales."

Einstein's general theory of relativity provides the basis for our understanding of gravity and proposes the existence of black holes.

image.caption: Brainbox ... Albert Einstein

article.caption: Einstein wrong (in theory, at least)
Einstein's wife feud revealed

caption.#: Einstein, a 'star' of science

pages.subdeck: Triumph ... George Galloway
pages.headline: Labour KOd by George Galloway
pages.teaser: MAVERICK Respect Party candidate's stunning victory in Bradford West by-election
pages.articlebody:
MAVERICK George Galloway celebrated a stunning by-election victory early today.

The Respect Party candidate inflicted a humiliating defeat on Labour in the Bradford West seat  knocking the Tories into third place.

Mr Galloway won with 18,341 votes, while Labour's Imran Hussain trailed in second with 8,201. Tory candidate Jackie Whiteley only managed 2,746 votes.

Joyful Mr Galloway, 57, declared that he had won a "big victory".

He added: "It is a very comprehensive defeat for New Labour. It is a pathetic performance by the Government parties."

It was the second time the anti-war politician had snatched a seat from Labour  the party that expelled him in 2003.

He enjoyed an election win in Bethnal Green and Bow in 2005. Yesterday's turnout was considered high at just over 50 per cent and Mr Galloway was particularly successful in Asian wards.

The by-election was held after serious illness forced Labour's Marsha Singh to stand down.

article.caption: Row gifts Labour a ten-point poll lead
Ed Miliband policy chief set to resign

image.caption: Triumph ... George Galloway

pages.subdeck: Brush with the law ... Anna Porreca was told paint was health and safety risk
pages.headline: Woman thrown off bus for carrying pot of paint
pages.teaser: FURIOUS housewife told it broke health and safety rules - but emulsion was safe
pages.articlebody:
A FURIOUS housewife was thrown off a bus because she was carrying a pot of white PAINT.

Anna Porreca, 52, was stunned when the driver told her she was a health and safety risk because the paint was flammable.

But the emulsion Anna had just bought from a DIY shop was water-based and completely safe.

She said: "The bus driver saw me getting on and said, 'You can't come on here with that'.

"I asked him why and he said it was to do with health and safety because it was flammable.

"I'm furious I checked the tin and it doesn't say that anywhere."

Anna, of Merthyr Tydfil, South Wales, had to call a relative to give her a lift home with her pot of paint and other shopping.

Transport firm Stagecoach is investigating why Anna was turned away from the bus.

A spokesman said: "We cannot comment until our investigations are complete."

image.caption: Brush with the law ... Anna Porreca was told paint was health and safety risk

pages.subdeck: Crowd pleaser ... young Jack Hill behind the decks
pages.headline: DJ record-breaker is just 11 years old
pages.teaser: PINT-sized Jack Hill can barely see over the decks but has set a world record for most songs mixed in 60 seconds
pages.articlebody:
AN ELEVEN-YEAR-OLD boy has set a world record for mixing the most songs in 60 seconds  despite having a broken hand.

Officially the world's youngest working DJ, Jack Hill, from Weston-super Mare, had his spinning hand run over by a car just five weeks earlier.

Despite struggling to see over his decks, little Jack has made a big impression, gigging in Europe and even attracting the attention of world famous DJ Tiesto who got in contact with the youngster on Facebook.

The plucky lad first stepped into a DJ booth aged just THREE and became a world record holder after mixing ten songs in one minute.

Proud Dad Bob said "Jack was badly shaken by the accident and really upset that he couldn't spin any tunes for a while.

"To lift the gloom I suggested he makes a new world record - the youngest DJ to mix ten songs in one minute.

"Jack practised for a couple of days and said 'Dad I've done it'."

The talented youngster has manned his own radio show since he was eight and now has five world records to his name including youngest DJ and club DJ.

He's come a long way since he first stepped into his Dad's mobile disco booth aged three, gigging in Italy and Spain and getting a ten-minute mix played on Radio 1-Extra.

But Jack doesn't let his new-found fame phase him.

"I wasn't nervous because the mix is quite difficult and you only have six seconds per song to cue sync and mix so i didn't even have time to get nervous," he said.

image.caption: Crowd pleaser ... young Jack Hill behind the decks

pages.subdeck: Tot a risk! ... little Sumit holds a snake as he learns the ancient art of charming
pages.headline: Little charmer
pages.teaser: LITTLE Sumit is taught ancient art of snake charming by his grandfather in remote region of India
pages.articlebody:
A TWO-YEAR-OLD boy plays carelessly with a deadly COBRA as his grandfather looks on proudly.

The pictures, which will be shocking to many British parents, show the dying tradition of snake charming in rural India.

For centuries, India's snake charmers have enjoyed a celebrated place in the country's history.

The hypnotic tunes they played to enchant snakes to dance have not only captured the imagination of Indians, but people around the world.

But now, the industry is fighting for its survival amid stringent wildlife protection laws.

Clad in a colourful turban, Budh Nath, 65, is training his young grandson to perfect the ancient art of making a snake dance to music - despite the fact it is illegal and he could be jailed if caught.

The family, who live in Faridabad, an hour's drive from Delhi, claim they used to make a good living and were respected as highly-skilled performers.

But since the late 1990s, when the Wildlife Protection Act (1972) was implemented, members of the nomadic Bedia community have seen their meagre finances dwindle still further.

The Act bars people from using wild animals commercially or turning them into pets, including bans on performances with live snakes. But the largely illiterate Bedia community have no other source of income.

Two-year-old Sumit is encouraged by his family to play with cobras, carelessly wrapping them around his neck, as they expect him to continue the family tradition..

Budh said: "I have educated all my sons and all my grandchildren go to school, but I will always teach them our ancient ways so we do not forget our heritage."

Snake charmers, once a symbol of the mystical Indian culture, have all but disappeared in recent years.

The new laws are to blame - anyone who owns a snake can face hefty fines and up to seven years in prison.

Budh added: "For thousands of years we have earned our living by entertaining people with snakes but now we are left penniless.

"Earlier, we used to roam from village to village and do our shows, but now if the police see us performing they take us to jail.

"Before they banned us from performing, we could make a decent living - we could get our sons educated, our daughters married. Now it is very difficult."

Snake charmers used to perform on street corners, festivals and in the early days of Indian independence at international art festivals.

Armed with a long gourd flute, called a been, the charmer would coax the snake, usually a deadly cobra, from the basket by swaying their instrument from side-to-side.

The snake, appearing hypnotised, follows the movement of the instrument with its head, appearing to dance.

Budh said: "We still do private performances at hotels but only for people we know. Otherwise, you never know when the police will try to arrest us and take our snakes away."

His shy six-year old grandson, Karan, regularly ignores his homework to practice playing the flute. "I love playing with snakes," he said.

"When I grow I want to be a snake charmer like my grandfather."

image.caption: Tot a risk! ... little Sumit holds a snake as he learns the ancient art of charming

pages.subdeck: Doomed ... James Kouzaris, left, and James Cooper on Florida holiday
pages.headline: They will haunt you
pages.teaser: FRIEND of two Brits shot dead in Florida bravely confronts murderer across a courtroom
pages.byline: By ANTHONY FRANCE and PAUL THOMPSON in Sarasota, Florida
pages.articlebody:
A FRIEND of two Britons shot dead in Florida told their killer across a courtroom: "They will haunt you."

Brave Joe Hallett directly addressed sneering teenager Shawn Tyson after sitting through days of harrowing evidence and distressing photographs.

Tyson, 17, had just been convicted of the murders of tourist pals James Kouzaris, 24, and James Cooper, 25, in a rundown public housing estate in the city of Sarasota.

Joe  who attended four days of the trial with another British friend Paul Davies  stood and looked Tyson straight in the eye as he told him: "You have taken us all on a journey to hell."

In an emotional impact statement, the killer was forced to listen to Joe saying: "I want you to think of my friends who you murdered.

"James Kouzaris and James Cooper continue to inspire those who knew them yet they will haunt your thoughts to the day you die.

"You pierced both of their hearts with bullets and you robbed them of their dignity, their freedom and their futures.

"You have ripped the hearts out of so many of us. Shawn Tyson, I need you to understand the pain you have caused and the amazing personalities that you have killed."

Joe also asked Tyson to try to think of two people he loved.

He said: "Imagine them being killed. Imagine that they died because someone crept up on them and shot them numerous times for no good reason. Welcome to our world."

Joe and Paul were both given the chance to speak directly to Tyson after he had declined to say anything in his own defence.

Yesterday a photo of the word "Savage" tattooed on the killer's chest emerged for the first time. But he avoided the death penalty because of his age and instead will be in prison until he dies.

When Judge Rick De Furia asked if he wanted to say anything before sentence was passed, Tyson mumbled: "No."

In Paul's impact statement he told the gunman  just 16 at the time of the killings on April 16 last year  he was a coward.

He said Tyson had killed his friends when they were lost, drunk, defenceless and pleading for their lives.

And he added: "You might think being a man is about carrying a gun around but it isn't. Wearing a mask and shooting two guys in cold blood is being a coward.

"Being a man is about recognising that you are only on this planet once and that you are judged on your actions while you are alive."

Tyson had earlier looked bored as DVD presentations prepared by their parents about the dead men's lives, from childhood to manhood, were shown in court.

None of the parents attended the trial but they had access to the proceedings from a live video feed. In their own statement they told of their heartbreak at the deaths and anger that Tyson, who had been arrested the day before for shooting at a car but allowed out of custody, was roaming free.

The hoodlum was often seen with a gun in the area where he lived with his mother.

The parents said: "Ours is a life sentence, with no chance of parole from a broken heart, and a shattered soul.

"The agonising and searing pain we have experienced will continue until our sentence is at an end.

"The evil of the killer is one thing. But he would not have been on the streets had instructions to keep him incarcerated been passed from one judge to another."

Court prosecutor Karen Fraivillig read a statement from James Cooper's parents Stan and Sandy, from Hampton Lucy, Warwicks, which said: "No words can express the despair, disbelief and desolation. We will miss him every minute of every day in a home that now feels empty."

In a video played to the court James Kouzaris' parents Pete and Hazel, of Northampton, said their son had been "needlessly taken from us in a moment of madness".

Pete said: "The 16th of April 2011 will be etched in the hearts and the memories of all those people who loved James."

Tennis coach James Cooper had been to Australia and played Andy Murray, while town planner James Kouzaris had taught English in Taiwan and travelled through central America before visiting Sarasota.

On the fateful night the friends had gone out to eat and drink downtown.

Witnesses testified Tyson told them he saw two "crackers"  a derogatory term for white people  and planned to rob them.

a.france@the-sun.co.uk



Obama 'ignored' parents' anguish

THE parents of the two murdered Brits have accused Barack Obama of a "lack of compassion" over the case.

They revealed that three letters they sent to the President at the White House were IGNORED.

And they claimed their sons were "not worthy of ten minutes of his time" because there was no "political value" for him.

Paul Davies, a friend of the two students, read a statement on behalf of their families after Tyson had been sentenced.

It said: "We would like to publicly express our dissatisfaction at the lack of any public or private message of support or condolence from any American governing body or, indeed, President Obama himself.

"James's dad has written to Mr Obama on three separate occasions and is yet to receive the courtesy of a reply.

"It would perhaps appear that Mr Obama sees no political value in facilitating such a request, or that the lives of two British tourists are not worthy of ten minutes of his time."

The embarrassing rebuke follows the President's personal intervention last week into the shooting of a black teenager by a white man in Florida.

Mr Obama said that if he had a son he'd have looked like 17-year-old victim Trayvon Martin.

Last night it was also revealed how an "administrative error" allowed Tyson to be released from juvenile detention just 24 hours before the murders.

He had been arrested on April 7, 2011, for shooting at a car but was freed into his mother's care on April 15.

article.caption: Teen guilty of murdering 2 Brit tourists in Florida
Shot Florida Brits pleaded for lives

caption.#: Slaughtered Brits found half-dressed

video.caption: TEEN Shawn Tyson jailed for gun murders of British pair in Florida

image.caption: Doomed ... James Kouzaris, left, and James Cooper on Florida holiday

pages.subdeck: Scam ... Nina Raymont at court
pages.headline: 30-year I.D. theft mum fiddles £30k
pages.teaser: CON artist Nina Raymont, 58, had been living a double life
pages.byline: By ANDY CRICK and AMANDA REVELL WALTON
pages.articlebody:
A DEVIOUS mum swindled £30,000 benefits after stealing the identity of a woman she met 30 YEARS ago.

Con artist Nina Raymont, 58, obtained a passport and National Insurance number in the name Sandra Forshaw and lived a double life.

She left the country to travel the world, raised two children and became a successful businesswoman.

But well-spoken Raymont returned to Britain in 2009 and started raking in benefits under her alias.

Over three years she fiddled £13,000 in pension credits and £17,367 housing benefit.

Council officials eventually spotted she was claiming under the names Raymont and Forshaw.

Cops raided her home in Oxford and found bank statements and a California driving licence in the name of Forshaw.

Legal papers, including the real Miss Forshaw's father's will, were also unearthed.

When she first appeared before magistrates last June, Raymont lied under oath still claiming to be Sandra Forshaw.

But yesterday the grey-haired swindler escaped jail despite her 30-year scam.

Raymont was given a 12-month suspended sentence and 250 hours of community service at Oxford Crown Court.

She pleaded guilty last month to six charges  two of obtaining false passports by deception, three of fraud and one of perjury.

Judge Gordon Risius said her deceit had taken "some planning."

He added: "Benefit fraud is also a serious offence, not least because it involves public money which can often not be recovered."

Swindling worker

in jail let-off

A TRUSTED civil servant who diverted £24,000 of benefits cash into her account was spared jail yesterday.

Samantha Douglas, 30, used her job as an administrative officer at the Department of Work and Pensions to pay herself 17 times.

Five years earlier she forged her partner's signature to get £22,500 in loans.

Douglas, of Wrexham, North Wales, admitted fraud and forgery. But the court in Chester heard she was a single parent struggling to keep a roof over her head.

She was given a 51-week prison sentence, suspended for two years.

a.crick@the-sun.co.uk

article.caption: Sick scam dog guru at Crufts
£1.7m 'con' by JobCentre staff
Benefits scrounger busted after becoming top archer
Benefits cheat told to sell home after being caught on water slide

image.caption: Scam ... Nina Raymont at court

pages.subdeck: Arrested ... masked special forces police escort a suspect in handcuffs
pages.headline: Terror cops swoop on 20 suspects in France
pages.teaser: DAWN raids follow death of Muslim fanatic who shot seven people in killing spree
pages.articlebody:
ELITE anti-terrorist police swooped on 20 suspected Islamic extremists in dawn raids across France today.

The arrests came after a French Muslim fanatic shot dead seven people in a killing spree this month  which President Nicolas Sarkozy has described as France's 9/11.

Those arrested in the co-ordinated busts were suspected of having links to banned radical Islamic group Forsane Alizza, police sources revealed.

But officials said the raids were "not directly related" to the shootings by self-confessed al-Qaeda follower Mohamed Merah in Toulouse and Montauban, south west France.

A police source said several guns and a bullet-proof vest were seized in the raids in the Paris region, Toulouse and the western city of Nantes.

All the men arrested are being quizzed at high security police stations under France's anti-terror laws, meaning they can be held for up to 96 hours before being charged.

As domestic security becomes a key issue in next month's presidential election, Mr Sarkozy today compared the killings to the Twin Tower attacks in New York 11 years ago.

He told Europe 1 radio this morning: "What must be understood is that the trauma of Montauban and Toulouse is profound for our country, a little  I don't want to compare the horrors  a little like the trauma that followed in the United States and in New York after the attacks on September 11, 2001."

Merah, 23, shot dead three soldiers in Montauban earlier this month, then days later gunned down a Rabbi and three children at the Ozar Hatorah school Jewish school in Toulouse.

He died in a hail of gunfire while leaping from a window after a 32-hour siege at his flat ended last Thursday.

His brother Abdelkader was last week charged with aiding a terrorist after traces of explosives were found in his car.

It later emerged that Merah may have spied for the French secret service in the Middle East before carrying out his ten-day rampage.

image.caption: Arrested ... masked special forces police escort a suspect in handcuffs

pages.subdeck: Probe ... police with truck
pages.headline: Twitter ghouls
pages.teaser: GHOULS took pictures of a woman decapitated by a truck  then posted them on Twitter
pages.articlebody:
GHOULS took pictures of a woman decapitated by a truck yesterday  then posted them on Twitter.

The victim's body parts were strewn across a busy commuter road as she was hit by a 40-ton articulated lorry that was driven on without stopping.

And witnesses took photos of the grisly scene with their phones before posting them on the social network site.

One picture, later deleted, showed a severed leg. A disgusted Twitter user called the snap-happy passers-by "sick".

He said: "It was revolting, like nothing I've ever seen. There were also some builders nearby filming it on their phones."

The 47-year-old truck driver was traced as he made a delivery three miles away. He was held on suspicion of murder but was later released without charge. Last night police were trying to determine how the Asian woman was killed on the road near Manchester's Royal Infirmary.

It was thought she may have jumped into the path of the lorry from an office block, or walked in front of it.

j.atkinson@the-sun.co.uk

image.caption: Probe ... police with truck

pages.subdeck: Hate campaign... Francecca
pages.headline: Yobs prey on disabled children
pages.teaser: DISABLED kids are more than twice as likely to be beaten up than other children their age
pages.byline: By GRAEME WILSON, Deputy Political Editor
pages.articlebody:
DISABLED children are more than TWICE as likely to be beaten up by thugs than other kids their age, figures reveal.

One in every six aged between ten and 15 suffered a violent attack last year.

And in three in every four cases the assaults  many involving knives, bricks and sticks  caused injury, Home Office figures reveal.

Overall, nearly one in five disabled or long-term sick children were crime victims  compared with one in nine without a disability or illness.

The figures revealed just over half of all attacks on children were in or near a school. Seven per cent of children suffered "serious" injury.

In nearly nine out of ten cases, victims knew their attackers, and in almost a quarter there were more than four. Seven in 10 victims did NOT think the attacks on them were crimes.

Tory MP Philip Davies said "Crime victims are often the most vulnerable people in our communities.

"That's why we need a justice system that's tough on the thugs and bullies who prey on the innocent."

Yesterday's shock statistics follow outrage at the ten-year hate campaign by vile young bullies which drove Fiona Pilkington to kill herself and disabled daughter Francecca, 18, in a car fire in Barwell, Leics.

g.wilson@the-sun.co.uk

Third of teachers attacked

ONE in three teachers has faced physical violence in the classroom in the last few months, a survey found.

Members of the Association of Teachers and Lecturers said they had been pushed, shoved, punched, hit and kicked.

And nearly half of the 814 polled said children's behaviour had got worse in the last two years. One primary teacher said: "A pupil once hit me in the back totally unexpectedly because I had asked her to put a book away."

ATL members said poor parenting was often to blame.

caption.#: Thugs rob disabled teen of his voice

image.caption: Hate campaign... Francecca

pages.subdeck: Struggling ... BlackBerry has failed to keep pace with Apple's touch-screen gadgets
pages.headline: BlackBerry crushed as gadget fans prefer taste of Apple
pages.teaser: MOBILE maker reports massive losses as iPhones and Androids dominate market
pages.articlebody:
BLACKBERRY maker Research In Motion has reported massive losses  as Apple's iPhone and Android-powered devices continue to dominate the smartphone market.

The Canadian gadget manufacturer revealed it lost $125million (£78million) in the last quarter of the financial year, compared with a profit of $418million (£260million) a year earlier.

Revenues for the period of $4.2billion (£2.6billion) were down 25 per cent from a year ago and below market expectations.

It means the company made a total profit of $1.16billion (£725million) in the last year  down sharply from $3.4billion (£2.1billion) the year before.

The results are disappointing for new RIM chief executive Thorsten Heins, who was brought in to reshuffle the struggling firm. Last night, he refused to rule out selling the company.

Mr Heins said he would be open to hearing purchase offers, and said the group would undertake a "comprehensive review of strategic opportunities".

He also warned the pain isn't over and the company's sales and profit will be under pressure for the next year.

Previously, he has said he wasn't interested in selling the company. But after two months in the job, he said he realised the challenges facing the company are much more significant than he initially thought.

Share prices have fallen 80 per cent since little more than a year ago, and RIM said it would write off $267million (£167million) worth of unsold BlackBerry 7 models.

By contrast, Apple saw its sales rise 73 per cent in the run-up to Christmas.

In a statement, Mr Heins said: "I have assessed many aspects of RIM's business during my first ten weeks as CEO.

"I have confirmed that the company has substantial strengths that can be further leveraged to improve our financial performance, including RIM's global network infrastructure, a strong enterprise offering and a large and growing base of more than 77million subscribers."

But he admitted: "It is now very clear to me that substantial change is what RIM needs."

Shares in RIM were down two per cent last night.

image.caption: Struggling ... BlackBerry has failed to keep pace with Apple's touch-screen gadgets

pages.articlebody:
GRAB your copy of Saturday's Sun for just 50p  and you will get TV buzz absolutely free.

This week Sir Tom Jones opens up about doing battle on The Voice UK.

And Britain's Got Talent judge Simon Cowell spills the gossip about his night dressed as a lady.

Read it all in Saturday's FREE mag.

pages.subdeck: Video row ... Tulisa Contostavlos and Justin Edwards
pages.headline: Tulisa ex in 'Playboy tape bid'
pages.teaser: X FACTOR judge says she was warned in October that he was trying to broker a deal
pages.articlebody:
X FACTOR judge Tulisa Contostavlos claims ex Justin Edwards tried to sell the sex tape of her to Playboy.

The allegation was set out in the latest judgment from the Royal Courts of Justice in her ongoing legal battle.

In them, Tulisa, 23, says she was warned in October 2011 that he was trying to broker a deal with the magazine.

She told lawyers to contact Edwards, 28  also known as MC Ultra  to tell him to stop.

He responded by insisting she had made the tape and that he had no copies. Edwards stressed that he had never tried to sell any footage.

Last week Edwards was slapped with a £100,000 claim for damages for alleged breach of privacy and confidentiality after the six-minute video was leaked online.

image.caption: Video row ... Tulisa Contostavlos and Justin Edwards

pages.subdeck: Tests ... bacteria were found in organ transplant fluid
pages.headline: Bug scare for organ patients
pages.teaser: FLUID used to transport organs could be contaminated with food-poisoning bug
pages.articlebody:
HUNDREDS of transplant patients could be at risk after foreign BACTERIA were found in the liquid used to preserve most donor organs.

Viaspan is used when transporting kidneys, livers, pancreases and bowels around the country.

Makers Bristol-Myers Squibb last night issued a recall of the product after recent tests on its production line revealed the presence of the bacteria Bacillus cereus. It is best known for producing a toxin in food which causes food poisoning.

The line was previously tested in July and the firm said it cannot guarantee the safety of Viaspan since that date.

Hundreds of Britons have received organs since July. But there is currently NO evidence that any have suffered  so the NHS will keep using the fluid until an alternative is found.

The Government's chief medical officer Dame Sally Davies said transplant patients can be prescribed an antibiotic in case the bug is present.

She added: "Our priority is to ensure patients are safe. There is currently no evidence of any problems in patients who have recently had transplants where Viaspan has been used. If we were to recall the product immediately it is clear that patients would suffer and some may die." The Department of Health is now "working urgently" to source alternative fluids.

Professor Sir Kent Woods, of the Medicines and Healthcare products Regulatory Agency, said: "We are working closely with the NHS to make alternative products available for transplant operations."

There are around 800 liver, 250 pancreas and 40 bowel transplants a year.

e.ashton@the-sun.co.uk

image.caption: Tests ... bacteria were found in organ transplant fluid

pages.headline: Toffs at trough
pages.teaser: READ The Sun Says leader comment to see our take on pressing issues of the day
pages.articlebody:
NOT a vote has been cast and already the Tories have managed to get taxes down.

Labour's surrender on 10 per cent extra cider duty is a triumph for David Cameron.

The Tories also blocked Labour's planned broadband tax.

Not a bad start as the Tories were clear winners on Day One of the election campaign.

In the Commons, Mr Cameron exposed Gordon Brown's weasel words over Labour's jobs tax.

Mr Brown says the business world has been deceived by the Tories into thinking that Labour's National Insurance tax rise will cost jobs.

Business leaders say Mr Brown is patronising, "economically illiterate" and insults their intelligence.

Almost seventy of Britain's biggest employers  including one of Mr Brown's own advisers  say the Tories are RIGHT.

The Sun agrees. Making firms pay more in tax for every person hired means bosses take on fewer workers.

Only in the warped world of Gordon Brown does raising National Insurance help unemployment.

The fed-up business community has washed its hands of union-run Labour.

Employers think that there will be more REAL jobs under the Tories.

Exactly what the country needs to hear.

Blaze heroes

FIREMEN didn't hesitate when they arrived at a blazing block of high-rise flats.

They plunged straight in  and two tragically lost their lives.

The Sun pays tribute to Hampshire fire heroes James Shears and Alan Bannon.

The brave men and women of our emergency services are very special.

When it comes to the crunch, they lay their lives on the line for us.

We are very lucky. We should be grateful and never forget their sacrifice.

Brave champ

TENNIS ace Martina Navratilova faces another tough challenge.

The legendary champ is diagnosed with breast cancer at the age of 53.

Not even a superfit athlete like Martina is safe from a cancer that affects women indiscriminately.

Many Sun readers will have a relative or friend who has been struck down.

Cancer survival rates in Britain have improved over the years. But they lag behind much of Europe and America, where Martina is optimistic about her prospects.

Yes, times are tough. But our next Government must do much more to improve our record on survival rates for breast and other cancers.

Brave Martina, who never gave up on court, will not give up on this fight either.

pages.subdeck: Sad ... fox yesterday
pages.headline: 'Mythical' black fox run over
pages.teaser: CREATURE was hit just days after being caught on camera by an amateur photographer
pages.articlebody:
A RARE black fox was yesterday run over and killed days after being caught on camera by an amateur photographer.

The animal, described as a "mythical" creature, was spotted by John Moore, 58.

When he told pals what he had seen, they said he must be mistaken. So John went out and took photos to prove it. The animal was run down on a busy road in Bassingbourn, Cambridgeshire, near where it was first seen by John.

An ambulance was flagged down by locals, but the animal could not be saved. John said: "It's really sad, especially as it's so rare."

But he believes he may have spotted another in the area, perhaps a cub.

The only other black fox to be seen in Britain was reported in Preston, Lancashire, in 2008.

The fox's black coat is believed to be caused by a genetic flaw.

Black foxes are said to bring bad luck.

article.caption: Brush with a black fox

caption.#: 21st Century

article.caption: 15st man mugged by a fox

image.caption: Sad ... fox yesterday

pages.subdeck: It's bob a hijab ... the new uniform for Muslims
pages.headline: New girl Scouts' uniform designed especially for Muslims revealed
pages.teaser: LONG-sleeved black hoodie dress created after surge in number of Muslim Scouts
pages.articlebody:
THIS is the new girl Scouts' uniform  designed especially for Muslims.

The long-sleeved black hoodie dress  worn here with traditional Muslim headscarf the hijab  features a pattern inspired by the movement's famous badges.

It was created by designer Sarah Elenany after the number of Muslim Scouts in the UK surged to more than 2,000 out of nearly 500,000.

image.caption: It's bob a hijab ... the new uniform for Muslims

pages.subdeck: Delighted ... Lindsay Lohan leaves court
pages.headline: Lindsay Lohan gets her freedom back
pages.teaser: LINDSAY'S DUI probation is ended after judge praised actress for her progress
pages.articlebody:
LINDSAY Lohan is finally a free woman  after an LA judge ended her probation.

The actress hugged her lawyer Shawn Chapman Holley yesterday following her court victory, marking the end of her sentence imposed after she was caught drink-driving in 2007.

Superior Court Judge Stephanie Sautner's ruling means Lindsay will no longer need to appear in court or report to a probation officer.

However, she's still on informal probation for stealing a £1,570 necklace from a boutique in Venice Beach, LA, last year.

But the big news is that the Mean Girls star no longer faces the immediate threat of jail or further punishment if she puts a foot wrong.

Lindsay has suffered a turbulent time since she her two DUI arrests  she was in and out of rehab and prison for much of 2010.

But she's largely steered clear of trouble over the past year and there are signs of a comeback in her ailing movie career.

Having guest-hosted Saturday Night Live, the actress is due to make a cameo in hit show Glee and is set to star as the late Elizabeth Taylor in a TV movie.

Judge Sautner praised Lindsay for the progress she has made and the star thanked the official for her patience.

She said: "I just want to say thank you for being fair. It's really opened a lot of doors for me."

image.caption: Delighted ... Lindsay Lohan leaves court

Lindsay Lohan in alleged hit and run
Lindsay Lohan lolli-pops to the shops
Lindsay's red hot again

pages.subdeck: JLS and paintball pals ... Gaz Batey is third from right on the back row
pages.headline: One shot.. one minder in hospital
pages.teaser: BOY band end up in hospital after SHOOTING their biggest minder during paintball game
pages.articlebody:
MOST days it's JLS who need protecting by their bodyguards.

But the lads ended up hospitalising their biggest minder yesterday  when they SHOT him in the throat.

Luckily it was just a paintball pellet. But it still did a fair bit of damage as the rounds travel at almost 200mph.

Crack shot Oritse blasted man-mountain Gaz Batey in his Adam's apple while playing a competitive round of war games with the band's security team in Manchester.

Gaz was last night recovering in bed but was still unable to speak.

A pal of the group, whose hits include One Shot and She Makes Me Wanna, said: "Gaz is 6ft 5in and 18st so he's their biggest asset when it comes to protecting them. He's not hard to miss so he was the biggest target of the day. Oritse is mad about paintball and prides himself on being the best.

"But there's no way he meant to hit Gaz in the throat.

"He was devastated when he realised what had happened and he hasn't stopped apologising since." Gaz was also struck in the arm by a pellet during the game and had to be carted off to A&E after he was hit in the neck.

JLS boys Marvin, JB and Aston have been winding up Oritse, saying that he is in for payback once the muscleman is back on his feet.

A source added: "The lads know Gaz won't forget this.

"He's laughed it off, but undoubtedly there will be some prank or payback." Oritse waited in A&E until Gaz got the all-clear and is planning to buy a gift to say sorry.

It won't just be flowers either.

The lads are known for their charitable ways.

It's believed they gave £25,000 each to Sport Relief yesterday.

Marvin will soon get hitched to The Saturdays star Rochelle Wiseman  Oritse had better watch himself on the stag do.

article.caption: JLS hit boat again
Roch 'n' roll birthday

pages.subdeck: Fright path ... pigeons give Niall Horan the creeps
pages.headline: One Direction crisis as birds flock to US gigs
pages.teaser: EXCLUSIVE: Boyband bring in extra security to protect star Niall Horan from PIGEONS
pages.articlebody:
BOYBAND One Direction are having problems with birds in the US  Niall Horan's terrified of PIGEONS.

Niall, 18, has had the phobia since one attacked him in the loo when he was a kid.

The X Factor stars have brought in extra security on their promo tour of America to remove pigeons at outdoor gigs.

Niall, whose bird fear condition is known as ornithophobia, said: "I get really nervous if pigeons are flying around before shows.

"I can't stand them after one once flew in through my bathroom window and went for me while I was having a wee. That was enough. I think pigeons target me."

Bandmate Harry Styles, 18, said: "Niall's really scared of pigeons. We have to protect him."

myView

By CAROL COOPER, Sun Doctor

A PHOBIA of pigeons is fairly common, often after visiting somewhere pigeons gather in huge flocks.

The symptoms include palpitations, breathlessness, dizziness, feeling sick, excess sweating, dry throat and  in extreme cases  fainting.

It can be treated  but it may be easier just to avoid places where pigeons flock in large numbers.

stuart.pink@the-sun.co.uk

pages.subdeck: Confident look ... Jessie J
pages.headline: Jessie J Lycs to grab attention
pages.teaser: SINGER looks like superhero as she dons tight-fitting Lycra outfit for gig in London
pages.articlebody:
JESSIE J looked like a comic superhero during a night out  in a Lycra top and trousers echoing the stony skin of The Thing.

Naturally, the singer and judge on The Voice is a lot prettier than the Fantastic Four character.

But the daring outfit nearly managed to overshadow her new hairdo  after she had her tips dyed blonde.

Jessie  seen rehydrating with vitamin water after a show at the Lounge Lover bar in Shoreditch, East London  recently revealed why she preferred joining the BBC's The Voice to Simon Cowell's talent shows.

She told The Sun: "A lot of people were, like, 'Why aren't you doing Britain's Got Talent or The X Factor?'

"But I think it's really important in your career to pick things that really represent you as a person."

Jessie decided to sign up to the £22million talent show  which launched last Saturday night  because she wanted people to see a different side to her feisty on-stage persona.

She said: "It's very scary but very exciting. But you know what? I'm just excited because I get to see a different side of things and people get to see me in a completely different scenario.

"I'm not singing and it's not me doing a three-minute TV performance, so people get to see my personality and really see that I have a passion for what I do. That's what I'm most excited about, people getting to see that I am a bit silly, make jokes and get told off.

"But I'm also a hard worker and care about technique and the artist, and I get very emotional."

caption.#: Jessie J-ust dyed her hair again

article.caption: Jessie J: I'm all about The Voice
Jessie J's secret dates with rapper Tinie Tempah
Jessie J to write autobiography
