pages.subdeck: Weight to go ... Billie the cat, from Sunderland, with veterinary nurse
pages.headline: Heavy petting
pages.teaser: WEIGHT-LOSS contest for FAT PETS sees two rabbits, five cats and 11 dogs bid for prize
pages.articlebody:
THESE dumpy dogs, mega moggies and rotund rabbits are some of Britain's chubbiest pets.

But the lardy lumps are about to be put on a strict diet and fitness plan.

There are 11 dogs, five cats and two rabbits in the final of Pet Fit Club, the annual slimming competition, organised by leading veterinary charity PDSA.

Together the pets are carrying a combined excess weight of more than 24st  the equivalent of 380 tins of dog food or the weight of 35 average-sized cats.

And they're not alone  2.9million dogs and 3million cats in the UK are overweight.

The finalists will follow a healthy eating and exercise regime supervised by the charity.

The top slimmer will be revealed in September and win a year's worth of pet food and an animal-friendly holiday with their owner.

Here we introduce some of the porky pets.

Billie, 1st 5lbs (main image)



Ideal weight: 10lb

Owner Vilma Warren, from Sunderland, says: "Billie is a lovely old gentleman who would eat all the time if I let him. To help him exercise we have been walking him in the cul-de-sac where we live and he plods alongside us quite happily. But he is always happy to get home!"

Jack, 3st 6lbs



Breed: Cavalier King Charles spaniel

Ideal weight: 1st 8lb

Owner Rose Welch, of Stanmore, Middlesex, says: "We want to help raise awareness of the seriousness of this issue."

Samantha, 10lbs



Ideal weight: 8lb

Samantha was already very overweight when Amanda Hammond, of Wakefield, W Yorks, adopted her. She says: "It's awful to see Samantha struggling to get around. She must feel terrible."

Deco, 7st



Breed: Labrador

Ideal weight: 5st 7lb

Jan Green, of Bradford, claims her beloved pooch is very greedy. She says: "He will eat anything. He once stole 36 buns that our grandkids baked."

Fifi, 1st 6lbs



Ideal weight: 10lb

Owner Monica Bottomley, of Bradford, says: "Fifi tends to gorge herself at any opportunity and steals food right from people's plates."

Casper, 1st 5lbs



Breed: Long-haired tabby

Ideal weight: 10lb

Christine Collins, who lives with Casper in Edinburgh, says: "He is lovely but also lazy. I've struggled to keep his massive appetite under control."

Bailey, 6st 11lbs



Breed: Border collie

Ideal weight: 3st 11lb

Duncan Conner, of Glasgow, explains Bailey was housebound for six weeks after damaging his legs. He says: "We felt sorry for him so spoilt him rotten."

Bobby, 5lbs 4oz



Breed: Mini Lop

Ideal weight: 3lb 8oz

Owner Becky Magson, of Richmond, N Yorks, says: "I don't know why she has put on weight. I suspect she steals food from her companion, Huey. I'm worried about the effect on her health."

Maverick, 1st 8lbs



Breed: Blue long-haired

Ideal weight: 12lb

Maureen Doyle, of Edinburgh, says: "He puts his front paws on the table and will cry for food, despite being fed three times a day."

Billy, 3st 10lbs



Breed: Cocker spaniel

Ideal weight: 2st 11lb

Owner Jane Hunter, of Glasgow, says: "Billy loves treats but especially vegetables covered in gravy. It's difficult not to give in to his huge eyes."

pages.subdeck: You sexy thin ... Victoria Beckham flaunts her bod in mag
pages.headline: Size 6 Posh: I'm average woman
pages.teaser: VICTORIA Beckham claimed her super-slim figure matches that of the AVERAGE woman
pages.articlebody:
VICTORIA Beckham lives on a diet of steamed fish and raw vegetables, and can easily slip into a size six dress  but she has bizarrely claimed her super-slim figure matches that of the AVERAGE woman.

Even though the average British female sports size 16 clothing, the former Spice Girl believes she represents the general public.

Years of dieting have made Victoria one of the leanest women in Hollywood  despite recently giving birth to her fourth child by soccer star hubby David.

She showed off her toned body in a series of new swimwear shots for Harpers Bazaar magazine.

And the fashion designer is so convinced her tiny physique is the norm that she has replaced models with her own body when it comes to fitting dresses for her clothes line.

She now bases every outfit on her own measurements, draping the fabric over her hips and bust before deciding on a style for the item.

In a Harpers interview, she said: "We always joke that we have this fabulously gorgeous 17-year-old model who is six-foot-whatever and I say, 'OK, I'm going to put it on  I stand for the general public here.'

"It's how I work. I found it really difficult when I was pregnant and I couldn't do that.

"It's part of the process. I'll stand here in my knickers and start draping fabric over myself."

The star snacks on edamame beans and frozen grapes to relieve hunger  while her favourite drink is a glass of champagne, also low on calories.

At a meal to celebrate the 150th anniversary of fashion label Burberry in 2006, telly chef Jamie Oliver revealed that Victoria swapped the full roast dinner on offer for a plate of salad.

In the interview with the upmarket magazine, Victoria, 37, also revealed that she is a fan of quirky British actress Tilda Swinton, 51.

She said: "I'm quite obsessed with Tilda. I find her intriguing, very stylish, she clearly understands fashion."



myView



By GEMMA COLLINS TOWIE star, size 18

VICTORIA definitely doesn't have the figure of the average woman.

She's worked tooth and nail to be a size six. Old Spice Girls pictures show she was a size ten to 12. I love Victoria and especially looked up to her when she was a more normal size as it was more achievable when I was 12.

This industry rips you to shreds and she obviously felt the need to drop some pounds after comments about her smile and cheeks, even though they looked great in the 1990s.

If she's comfortable with her body now, brilliant, but she must realise it's not how the average person looks.

  • See Victoria Beckham's full photo shoot and interview in the May issue of Harper's Bazaar - on sale Monday 2nd April 2012

    c.mcguire@the-sun.co.uk

pages.subdeck: Warning ... health reports link alcohol to breast cancer risk
pages.headline: Why just ONE glass of wine might kill you
pages.teaser: STUDY shows drinking three or more a day can increase cancer risk by 40 PER CENT
pages.articlebody:
JUST one alcoholic drink a day can increase your risk of breast cancer, according to a new study.

Experts found even low and moderate drinkers had a five per cent greater risk of getting the disease.

Sinking three or more glasses a day can increase your risk of breast cancer by more than 40 PER CENT.

They say no woman should have more than ONE alcoholic drink a day  and those at a higher risk because of their family history should avoid booze completely.

Catherine Priestley, clinical nurse specialist at Breast Cancer Care, said: "This research says even light alcohol consumption could increase your risk.

"We think it can increase the levels of oestrogen in the body and this might increase the likelihood of breast cancer.

"The risk for every person is different. There may be teetotal women who develop breast cancer and there will always be women who drink a lot who don't get it.

"It's not as concrete as lung cancer and smoking but we would advise that people look at the information available and make an informed choice."

Here, we ask if you are drinking your way to breast cancer. Take the Sun Health quiz below to find out.



Take our test to discover your risk



1. HOW MANY DAYS OF THE WEEK DO YOU HAVE AN ALCOHOLIC DRINK?

1-2 (score 1 point)

3-4 (score 2 points)

5-6 (score 3 points)

Every day (score 4 points)

2. WHAT IS YOUR USUAL TIPPLE?

Spirit and mixer (score 1 point)

An alcopop (2 points)

Pint of lager (3 points)

175ml glass of wine (3 points)

250ml glass of wine (4 points)

3. HOW MANY DRINKS DO YOU TYPICALLY DRINK EACH DAY?

I don't drink alcohol (0 points)

1 (1 point)

2-3 (2 points)

4 or more (4 points)

4. HOW OFTEN DO YOU HAVE SIX OR MORE UNITS OF ALCOHOL ON ONE OCCASION?

Never (0 points)

Once a month (2 points)

2-4 times a month (3 points)

2-3 times a week (5 points)

5. HOW OLD WERE YOU WHEN YOU STARTED DRINKING?

15 or under (4 points)

16-18 (3 points)

18-21 (2 points)

21 or over (2 points)

6. HOW OFTEN DO YOU SUFFER FROM A HANGOVER?

More than once a week (4 points)

Once a week (3 points)

Twice a month (2 points)

Once a month (1 point)

7. DO YOU HAVE A FAMILY HISTORY OF BREAST CANCER?

Yes (1 point)

No (0 point)

8. DO YOU DRINK SOFT DRINKS IN BETWEEN ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES?

Yes (0 points)

No (2 points)

9. HOW OFTEN DO YOU EXERCISE?

Never (3 points)

1-2 times a week (2 points)

3-4 times a week (1 points)

5 times or more (0 points)

10. DO YOU DRINK BEFORE YOU GO OUT TO THE PUB?

Yes (2 points)

Sometimes (1 point)

No (0 points)



Scores and what they mean



OVER 30: DANGEROUS DRINKING. A greater chance of breast cancer, plus higher risk of liver disease, high blood pressure and stroke. Curb your drinking by changing your habits. You may also need help from your GP. Alcohol programmes are available in many areas.

21-30: HEAVY DRINKING. You could run a 40-50 per cent higher risk of breast cancer. There's also osteoporosis and high blood pressure to consider.

Try to avoid drinks that have become just a bad habit. Counselling may help you come to grips with problems that you can't see your way round at the moment. Again, your GP can help point you in the right direction. And see drinkaware.co.uk.

11-20: MODERATE DRINKING. You rarely overdo it and probably consider yourself a safe drinker. But the new research suggests that small amounts of alcohol, well below the current limits, can slightly increase the risk of breast cancer. They may also make fertility problems more common. Alternate soft drinks with alcoholic ones on an evening out.

Cutting down on alcohol can help you achieve your ideal weight because it is loaded with calories. Obesity increases the risk of breast cancer.

Keep active too. Lack of exercise can increase the risk of many common cancers, as well as heart disease.

0-10: ADMIRABLY RESTRAINED. But it's worth examining your lifestyle as a whole. A low-fat diet, regular exercise and giving up smoking will all give your health a boost.

pages.subdeck: Backing ... Hollyoaks actress Holly Weston
pages.headline: Meningitis kills teens as well as babies
pages.teaser: WITH a Hollyoaks character fighting for her life in the soap, actress who plays her reveals her support for new campaign
pages.byline: By HOLLY WESTON, Who gets struck down with the disease on Hollyoaks
pages.articlebody:
HOLLYOAKS student Ash Kane is fighting for her life in the Channel 4 soap  after being struck down with meningitis.

Ash initially put her symptoms down to a hangover. But in Tuesday's episode she collapsed and was rushed to hospital.

Holly Weston, 26  the actress who plays her  is backing Meningitis UK's Trust Your Instincts campaign.

Here, she tells us why.

I PLAY Hollyoaks party animal Ash, who was rushed to hospital with meningitis.

After a night out on the tiles, Ash woke up with a hangover after falling out with all her friends the night before.

When she complained of feeling unwell the next morning everyone just put it down to her usual melodramatics or the large amount of booze they thought she had drunk.

But Ash knew there was something wrong  she didn't drink enough to be that hungover and felt terrible.

During an argument with her sister, she collapses on the floor of the living room.

Not knowing what the problem is, her room mates call an ambulance and she is taken to hospital where she is diagnosed with meningitis and put into an induced coma.

It's touch and go whether she is going to be all right or whether she may be left with brain damage if she wakes up.

I knew very little about meningitis before tackling this storyline and during my research I was astonished to learn what an awful disease it is.

I had no idea that it could be so serious, that this disease can kill in just a few hours and leave people with permanent disabilities including loss of limbs and brain damage.

I also thought it was just something babies contracted.

I had no idea that it was so common in teenagers, who are the second most at-risk group after the under-fives.

Ash had some of the classic symptoms: Headache, a stiff neck and dislike of bright lights and feeling sick.

She put it down to flu but it soon became much more serious.

People always think of the rash  but this often doesn't appear until people are in a critical condition and there are many other symptoms to watch out for.

I am backing Meningitis UK's Trust Your Instincts campaign, which is encouraging people to seek urgent medical attention if they suspect meningitis.

The campaign encourages people to voice their concerns if they still fear something is wrong after seeking medical advice.

I hope that people read this and take notice that spotting the symptoms of meningitis early could save their life.

To request a free Meningitis UK symptoms fridge magnet to help you spot the signs of the disease, call 0117 947 6320 or visit the website meningitisuk.org.

pages.subdeck: Quirky ... Jessie J
pages.headline: What your clothes say about YOU
pages.teaser: BEHAVIOUR expert Dr Pam Spurr analyses six celebrities and reveals what their fashion tells us about their personality
pages.articlebody:
MOST of us flash more flesh as the weather warms up but we may not realise what our outfits reveal about our personality.

A new book by US psychologist Dr Jennifer Baumgartner, You Are What You Wear: What Your Clothes Reveal About You, claims to unwrap the secrets behind our choice of outfits.

Here behaviour expert Dr Pam Spurr analyses six celebrities and reveals what their style says about them.

Jessie J



Style: The singer's outlandish styles show she likes to do things her own way.

Style secret: Eccentric dressers may seem extrovert but are often shy deep down. Their clothes may act as armour, diverting attention from them.

Cameron Diaz

Style: The film star's relaxed look indicates a more carefree and grounded personality.

Style secret: When someone feels they are seen chiefly as a sex object, they may downplay their feminine side to show there is more to their character.

Kate, Duchess of Cambridge

Style: As a younger Royal, Kate could push the boat out more with her outfits but plays it safe.

Style secret: Kate probably likes to maintain routine and please others. But some conservative dressers may long to break free.

Christina Hendricks

Style: The vampish Mad Men actress can seem aloof and untouchable.

Style secret: Someone who dresses like this may not feel sexy inside. She might be over-compensating to cover insecurity.

Beyonce

Style: The singer's trademark jewellery reveals a powerful personality who is happy to show she is on top.

Style secret: Lots of flash or expensive gear can mask a deeper insecurity that makes the wearer feel a need to prove themself.

Holly Willoughby

Style: Holly's style is feminine and traditional, but with a twist of sexiness.

Style secret: The girl next door may secretly wish to be more assertive and outgoing. Often more complicated than she appears.

pages.subdeck: Busker to beauty queen ... Miss England contestant Lena Walker
pages.headline: From busker to beauty queen
pages.teaser: ENCOURAGEMENT from passers-by led to teenager entering beauty pageant
pages.articlebody:
A STUNNING busker has turned Miss England hopeful after her fans encouraged her to enter the beauty pageant.

Lena Walker took to the streets of her home city of Leicester with her guitar to raise money for charity.

But the 17-year-old was surprised when scores of people approached her to praise her music  and her good looks.

The pretty student said: "I decided to give busking a go  but never expected the reaction I got.

"Loads of people were coming up to me and commenting on my music, but also my looks."

After entering the Miss England contest, she battled through several rounds to make the national finals.

She added: "I've always been a down-to-earth girl, so had never really considered putting myself in to be judged on my looks.

"But after my family and friends said I should do it, and with the confidence of all the comments from the public, I thought why not."

And after beating off competition from 22 other girls, she will now compete in the Miss England final in Leicester on June 26.

Lena said: "I don't think it has really hit me that I've made it into the last 60 girls left from the whole UK.

"I'm sure it will sink in once I'm on that stage."

And she says she's looking forward to competing in front of her home crowd.

She said: "Hopefully my down-to-earth nature will shine through and win me some support.

"I'll have plenty of family and friends there, what with it being held in my home town.

"It could be a struggle fitting them all in!"

If things don't work out, Lena may still have a career in music  as she raised a whopping £35 an hour while busking

But the big-hearted student donated the cash she raised to charities.

She added: "The public have been very generous whenever I have put myself on a limb and taken to the streets to play my music.

"I play a lot of my own stuff that I write, but also play a few crowd-pleasers like David Guetta, Jessie J and Foster The People.

"On a good day I've made £35 an hour and would stay for a couple of hours at least.

"It isn't all glamour though. I'd often get back from a session busking and your fingers would be numb thanks to the cold."

pages.subdeck: 'My photo journey reminds me how hard I worked' ... Nicola Williams
pages.headline: 11st weightloss picture diary
pages.teaser: TEACHER shares snaps she took every month until she reached her goal...a size 12
pages.articlebody:
WHEN primary school teacher Nicola Williams decided to lose weight, she looked to herself for inspiration.

She decided to take a self-portrait every month to clearly see her progress and motivate her to continue.

Her inspiring photo casebook charts her epic FOUR-YEAR weight loss  from 24 stone and a size 32 to the 13 stone size 12 she is today.

Her incredible photo diary helped her jack in the junk food and bin the bad habits in pursuit of a healthier, happier life.

Now, looking back through the pictures proves incredibly emotional for Nicola, 39.

She says: "When I show people they stare open-mouthed as I flick through the album and shrink before their eyes.

I can't believe how big I was and how much I've transformed. It's incredible and I love the new improved me.

"My photo journey reminds me of how hard I worked to get where I am today and I hope it inspires other women to begin their own journey."

At the age of 24, Nicola was 16 stone and by the time she was 34 she weighed 24st.

She recalls: "I worried if I was going to fit through a small gap or get stuck on a small chair. So I'd try to avoid putting myself in potentially embarrassing situations.

"For breakfast, I'd have four slices of toast. For lunch I'd make a sandwich with four slices of white bread with double the filling.

"Dinners were always whatever was quick. Pasta bakes, pizzas and takeaways were my regular meals of choice.

"My biggest weakness though, were crisps. I'd never go a day without eating at least three bags.

"Working as a primary school teacher, the staff room is always full of cakes and chocolates to snack on during break times."

Nicola, of Llanelli, Wales, was eating around 4,900 calories a day, 2,900 above the recommended intake. And it affected her confidence.

She says: "Trying to run around with the kids during PE lessons and teaching them about healthy lifestyles was always difficult as I felt like a hypocrite."

She also struggled to find clothes to flatter her huge frame. She continues: "I had to settle for T-shirts that managed to cover my enormous body and trousers that didn't dig in to my sides.

"The only things that looked good were shoes. I loved being able to walk into High Street shops and pick out a pair of pretty high heels, slip them on my feet and feel sexy.

"So I went crazy for them. Platforms, stilettos, boots, wedges  you name them, I had a pair. In every colour and for every occasion I had shoes that made me feel great.

"Worth more than £3,500, I had just over 100 pairs in my collection before my life changed."

Then, in December 2007, Nicola joined a weekly slimming class  purely to keep a friend company.

She says: "I swapped white bread for brown, reduced my portion sizes and snacked on fruit and veg. I found it surprisingly refreshing to come out of my normal convenience eating routine and try something new."

Within a month, Nicola had shed 10lb. Yet she struggled to see a difference in her appearance.

"So my friend suggested taking a picture to show me how well I'd done. It was the motivation I needed to carry on," she says.

"Comparing myself month by month stunned me. My face was thinner and I could notice the difference in my waistline and arms.

"I began looking forward to each month when the time came to take a picture and compare myself to the previous one."

Nicola also joined women-only gym Curves and began working out twice a week.

She says: "After the first year I'd lost five stone  down from 24st to 19st.

"My meals changed completely to consist of a piece of toast for breakfast, a sandwich with two pieces of brown bread for lunch, fruit for a snack and meat with vegetables for dinner.

"Looking at myself filled me with pride and the compliments I was receiving from friends and family were incredible.

"I was determined this wasn't going to just be a fad diet phase  this was a new lifestyle for me."

In the next three years she lost a further six stone, dropping to 13st 2lb.

Nicola says: "Every woman wants to look their best in a photo.

"If I was ever tempted to have a take-away binge at the end of the month, I'd think about having my picture taken and it would put me off."

And for shoe-mad Nicola there was only one way to mark her sensational new figure.

"In January this year I splashed out on a beautiful pair of £380 cream Jimmy Choo shoes to celebrate."

pages.subdeck: Incredible figure ... mum-of-fourteen Nadya Suleman
pages.headline: 'Octomom' poses for topless snaps
pages.teaser: MUM-OF-FOURTEEN poses for topless snaps three years after having her octuplets
pages.articlebody:
MUM-of-fourteen Nadya Suleman shows off her incredible post-babies body in these revealing snaps.

Nadya, dubbed "Octomom" after giving birth to octuplets in 2009, happily posed topless for a magazine shoot.

And while she boasts of attracting plenty of admirers with her flat stomach and 34DD boobs, she claims she has been celibate for 13 years  as her children were all conceived through a sperm donor.

She explained: "I get way too much male attention, but I won't date until the octuplets are 18  I live for them now.

"I know a lot of women like male attention, but I'll go out with no make-up on and wear tracksuits, a wig and even a fake pregnancy stomach to put them off."

She added: "I wouldn't rule out a relationship in the future. But now, when men look at me, I look away and they know not to approach me.

"I know I'm beautiful  I don't need a man to tell me that."

Nadya, who lives in California, US, already had six kids  Elijah, now 10, Amerah, nine, Joshua, eight, Aiden, six, and twins Caleb and Calyssa, five, when she claims she decided to have more embryos implanted from the same sperm donor.

And her brood was soon joined by six boys and two girls  Noah, Jonah, Jeremiah, Isiah, Josiah, McCai, Maliah and Nariah, who turned three in January this year.

But amazingly, the 36-year-old says it was no effort at all to get her figure back following her last pregnancy.

She explained: "I just pinged back into shape like a rubber band after the kids  I don't know how I did it.

"I eat like a horse, don't count calories and have never owned a set of scales.

"I gained an entire human when I was pregnant with the octuplets  going from 10st to over 19st  but, two months later, I was a size eight again. Now, I never weigh myself."

  • The full feature appears in this month's Closer magazine, on sale now.

image.caption: Incredible figure ... mum-of-fourteen Nadya Suleman

pages.subdeck: Shine on ... glossy skin is season's must-have
pages.headline: Go with the glow
pages.teaser: FORGET heavy tans and thick layers of foundation  radiance is the key word on the catwalk
pages.articlebody:
THIS is the season to embrace dewy skin. Forget heavy tans, thick layers of foundation and cakey bronzer  radiance is now the key word in the beauty world.

Catwalk models have all been given little else but radiant, glowing skin, while celebrities such as Natalie Portman are setting the precedent for softer, fresher looks.

If YOU fancy brightening your complexion, a few simple tricks can lift your skin.

LAUREN NAYLOR shares her skin secrets so you can get up and glow.

Skin perfection



LET'S face it, we'd all love to feel confident make-up free and be blessed with a radiant, glowy complexion.

But daily exposure to harsh elements can make it difficult to pull off. Look out for nourishing and calming skincare ingredients to give your skin radiance and combat dryness and redness.

Head therapist Sherelle at celebrity skin care spa Linda Meredith, whose clients include Kate Beckinsale and Gwyneth Paltrow, says: "Start by using a cleanser packed full of naturally occurring vitamins, omega oils and amino acids.

"We are exposed to various chemicals throughout our day so look for paraben-free formulas.

"Take a generous amount of cleansing product mixed with warm water and with a feather-soft touch gently massage the product in with your fingertips.

"By massaging softly you are pushing the product into your skin rather than moving facial muscles about aggressively.

And the warm water heats the skin for the products to penetrate deeper. When you rinse, use a soft sponge, gentle cotton wool pads or your hands  flannels are too abrasive.

"An old-school, tried-and-tested method that we use is to give your skin a deep steam once a week over the basin. This will help open up and deep-clean any clogged pores.

"There is nothing wrong with squeezing out blackheads  just make sure you take a thick piece of tissue and use the sides of your fingertips to push them out.

"Only do this for three to five minutes max. If they won't come, they're not ready, and if you use your fingernails you will break and damage your skin."

We love REN Hydra-Calm Cleansing Milk with peroxidase enzymes from fennel seed extract to protect distressed skin and Omega 3 and 7 essential fatty acids to reduce inflammation, £18.

Linda Meredith Paraben-free Cream Cleanser with avocado and citrus fruit oils, £39 (stockists, 020 7225 2755). Team with a brightening moisturiser such as Simple Radiance Brightening Moisturiser, £6.99 (Boots).

Pep up



IF your complexion is looking lacklustre, it's likely you need to exfoliate sluggish skin cells. Look for natural ingredients that gently slough off dead skin.

Walnut shell, papaya and pineapple are all fantastic natural exfoliators. Try Origins Never A Dull Moment skin-brightening polisher with fruit extracts to help reveal a healthy glow, £24 (Origins).

Put your feet up and slather on Elemis Papaya Enzyme Peel, £28.60 (Elemis counters). We love the intoxicating Victoria sponge-like scent.

Make me up



SKIN highlighters add radiance in an instant. You can layer under make-up or wear stand-alone.

If you are going out and want to appear more made up, try adding highlighter along the cheekbones, down the bridge of the nose and on the forehead  this gives a shimmering dewiness.

You can also place highlighter on the brow bone and under the arch of the brow to make your eyes appear brighter.

L'Oreal Lumi Magique Concealer, £8.49, (Boots) will help to brighten the eyes if you dab a small amount in the darkest areas, ie, underneath, and Bobbi Brown Creamy Concealer in Chestnut, £17, is great for darker skins. Gorgeously rich and luxurious, MAC's Strobe Cream is used by many of the world's high-profile make-up artists.

Wear it under or over make-up for a dewy, almost wet-look effect and team with MAC's Lustre Drops in Sun Rush, £17.50, for a pop of warmth.

Last but not least, finish your face with a burst of brightening blusher on the apples of your cheeks such as Gosh Natural Blush in Electric Pink, Max Factor Miracle Touch Creamy Blush in Soft Pink, £6.99, or Maybelline NY Dream Soft Blush in Peach 02, £4.49 (all Superdrug).

Get more on National Cleavage Day including The Sun's cleavage Hall of Fame

But she wasn't the only celeb getting in on the action today.

Presenter Lisa Snowdon also posted a sexy photo of her cleavage online.

Xtra Factor host and singer Olly Murs tweeted his delight at hearing what day it was.

Even ex Strictly Robbie Savage tried to get in on the action, posted a photo with the message: "Heh #nationalclevegeday what you reckon.

"Happy cleavage day everyone lol lol !!"

And former Dancing On Ice star Laura Hamilton, who is is engaged to insurance broker Alex Goward, wrote: "Alex informs me it's national cleavage day today? Did he make that up? He he."

Imogen recently moaned that she'd wolfed down too many snacks while on holiday in Thailand earlier this month, and booked herself into a bootcamp.

Well she's got a point, she's busting out of her clothes.

SEAN CONLON, booted off The Voice, is having another stab at fame  by reuniting his old band 5ive.

Sean hooked up with his former bandmates in a London pub this week for the first time in five years and a greatest hits tour is on the cards.

Manager Tim Ferrone confirmed: "The lads talked about whether there was interest in a reunion.

"They all agreed this is something to work on and there has been lots of positive feedback from promoters.

"It would primarily be a comeback tour at this stage but there has been talk of new material."

In the Nineties, the band had hits including Got The Feelin'.

pages.headline: Freddie Flintoff: Snakes & spiders better than TOWIE
pages.teaser: CRICKET ace jokes he'd rather face fierce animals than Sam Faiers and her telly pals
pages.articlebody:
FREDDIE FLINTOFF came face-to-face with snakes, spiders and lions for his new TV show  but jokes it was better than having to spend time with The Only Way Is Essex cast.

The retired England cricket legend faced some of nature's fiercest predators in Australia, Borneo, Africa and Canada in his new nature show, Freddie Into The Wild.

It starts on May 24 on the Discovery Channel and Freddie insists it's a nature show inspired by Michael Palin and Sir Richard Attenborough and not a celebrity reality show.

Freddie said: "If you could put everything I don't like in one place, like the dark, the insects, well if you could add the cast of The Only Way Is Essex in there, you'd probably have everything.

"It was an amazing experience, but it was challenging."

Freddie is now training for a mammoth 21-day. 3,000-mile charity bike ride from Greece to London.

pages.subdeck: Getting bark to his old self ... Buddy with owner Pippa Langhorne
pages.headline: BGT singing dog Buddy in rehab
pages.teaser: EXCLUSIVE: Buddy, who reached semi-finals howling to Pie Jesu, couldn't cope
pages.articlebody:
A SINGING dog that starred on Britain's Got Talent has had to go to rehab.

Lhasa Apso puppy Buddy struggled to cope with fame following last year's series.

He delighted viewers and judges as he howled his way through Pie Jesu with owner Pippa Langhorne  reaching the semi-finals.

Buddy then continued his celebrity career off screen  visiting schools and events. But after initially enjoying the limelight all the attention became too much and he went into meltdown.

Pippa, 21, of Worcester, said: "He just couldn't cope with living every day in the spotlight and being around children or other dogs.

"He became aggressive  not biting, but barking and snarling, and he stopped singing. People would come over and he'd hide."

Worried Pippa cancelled all of Buddy's engagements and took him to dog behaviourist Lisa Jackson.

Lisa established Buddy was suffering with stress and anxiety from feeling constantly under pressure to sing.

Trained opera singer Pippa said: "Lisa said I had to take him out of any situation where he would feel like he needed to perform."

Four months on from his breakdown, Buddy is regaining his confidence.

Pippa said: "Now we do the occasional dog show and he enjoys himself."

Lisa said Buddy became scared of people and turned aggressive to make them go away. She added: "He's an awful lot better but is still a work in progress."

j.atkinson@the-sun.co.uk

pages.subdeck: Concern ... Simon Cowell's ex-lover Sinitta has urged the mogul to move home after break-in
pages.headline: Sinitta: I fear that a crazed fan might kill Simon Cowell
pages.teaser: BGT judge's ex-lover is urging him to move because she thinks a fan will murder him
pages.articlebody:
SIMON Cowell's ex-lover Sinitta is begging him to move house or "build a fortress" because she fears a deranged fan will murder the X Factor star.

Music mogul Simon was rocked when he came face-to-face with a female intruder on Saturday night.

She allegedly broke in through an upstairs bathroom window armed with a brick while he was watching himself on telly.

Sinitta described the incident as "like a nightmare" and urged Simon to rethink his security.

However, the singer  who dated Simon while he managed her pop career in the Eighties  fears he will be reluctant to quit his £9million west London mansion because he has spent so much cash renovating it.

She told TV Biz: "Simon has to come to terms with looking after himself properly now he's reached that level of fame.

"It's a scary thing. Hopefully the intruder didn't want to harm him but they could have.

"If it had been someone else with an obsession they could have killed him.

"I'm trying to persuade him to move or build a fortress around the house. It was alarming for him, it was like a nightmare. It can't happen again."

Simon has spoken to Sinitta on the phone since the "nightmare" event and has already moved to tighten his personal security.

Sinitta added: "He ought to move now so he doesn't have to worry but he has spent a fortune renovating his home, and he's been renovating it for so long.

"He's finally got it how he wants it so it would be a shame to move.

"I don't know if he would be able to get planning permission for huge gates and he probably wouldn't like that either.

"Personally, I got upset with his security. For me, where were they?"

On Monday, Leanne Zaloumis, 29, of Catford, south east London, appeared at West London Magistrates Court accused of aggravated burglary.

The charge claims she intended to inflict GBH.

She spoke only to confirm her personal details as she was remanded in custody until June.

However, Simon had a great weekend over all. His return to Britain's Got Talent pulled in 11.5million viewers while the BBC's new show, The Voice, attracted only 9.8million.

  • SINITTA has recorded A Bedtime Story With Arnie And Barnie on Nick Jr which will be screened in July.

pages.subdeck: In store ... Jeremy Piven and Katherine Kelly to star in Mr Selfridge
pages.headline: Jeremy Piven and Katherine Kelly in Mr Selfridge
pages.teaser: ENTOURAGE star and ex Corrie actress are starring in forthcoming ITV drama Mr Selfridge
pages.articlebody:
JEREMY Piven and former Corrie actress Katherine Kelly are to star in a new ITV1 drama about department store Selfridges.

Mr Selfridge will chart the life of flamboyant and visionary US entrepreneur Harry Gordon Selfridge - known as the Earl of Oxford Street.

Set in London in 1909, after he opened the doors of his lavish department store, Mr Selfridge is ITV's latest historical drama following Downton Abbey and Titanic and will be shown next year.

Entourage actor Jeremy, 46, will play the titular role while ex soap star Katherine, 32, who starred as Becky McDonald in Coronation Street, has been cast as socialite Lady Mae. She will be seen helping him build his empire.

The drama will run for ten hour-long episodes and is penned by Andrew Davies, the man behind TV adaptations of Bleak House and Pride And Prejudice.

The story is based on the book Shopping, Seduction And Mr Selfridge by Lindy Woodhead.

pages.subdeck: From Walford to witchcraft ... former EastEnder Lacey Turner joins spooky new drama Switch
pages.headline: Lacey s-witches to ITV2 for bewitching new role
pages.teaser: FORMER EastEnder Lacey Turner will play a witch in sassy new supernatural drama series Switch
pages.articlebody:
LACEY Turner has got a magic new role  as a witch.

The former EastEnder has been cast in ITV2's new supernatural drama Switch, about a group of four young women living in London, who just happen be witches.

It's not the first spooky role the 24-year-old has taken on since leaving Walford  where she played Stacey Branning for six years  in 2010.

Lacey also starred in BBC3's Being Human and also played the Bride of Frankenstein in a special live event from Kirkstall Abbey in Leeds.

In Switch, the award-winning actress is teaming up with The Inbetweeners' Hannah Tointon, another former EastEnder Nina Toussaint-White and Black Mirror's Phoebe Fox.

Lacey will play "immaculately dressed" careerist Stella, while Tointon is the "restless and spontaneous" Hannah, Toussaint-White is "sexy and stylish" fashionista Jude and Fox is the group's "moral compass" Jade.

As the four 'Witches of Camden', the girls must deal with the ordinary challenges of life in modern London, as well as facing their sworn enemies the 'Witches of Kensington.'

Produced by Being Human's Philip Trethowan and written by Chloe Moss (Prisoners' Wives) and Tim Price (Secret Diary of a Call Girl), the six-part series will start filming in London, Cardiff and Bristol next month.

ITV spokeswoman Laura Mackie said: "Switch is a contemporary series about friendship with a spell-binding twist.

"Chloe and Tim have created four fun-loving, free-spirited characters and we're delighted with the direction the series takes."

image.caption: From Walford to witchcraft ... former EastEnder Lacey Turner joins spooky new drama Switch

pages.subdeck: CREATIVE ... Alex Song has weighed in with eight assists for Arsenal this season
pages.headline: Ox: On Song Alex is just Fab
pages.teaser: ALEX OXLADE-CHAMBERLAIN reckons Alex Song has softened Cesc Fabregas' exit
pages.articlebody:
ALEX OXLADE-CHAMBERLAIN reckons Alex Song has filled the creative void Cesc Fabregas left in Arsenal's midfield.

Cameroon international Song has been a key part in the Gunners' resurgence following their poor start to the Premier League campaign.

He has weighed in with eight assists so far this season  the same as Tottenham's Gareth Bale and Manchester United winger Nani.

Song set up two of Robin van Persie's most memorable efforts with superb through balls for the Dutchman's goals against Everton and Liverpool.

And Chamberlain claims Song's increased creativity has helped the North Londoners forget about £36million Spanish ace Fabregas, who re-joined Barcelona last summer.

The Ox said: "Some of the passes he has been putting in, like for two of the unbelievable volleys Robin has scored, reminds me technically of watching Fabregas put those balls through.

"For a holding midfielder to do that, as well as the defensive side of the game, is brilliant. You can't ask for anything more.

"I can't remember the last game he didn't play  he is always there.

"Sometimes you don't notice the stuff he does, the defensive side of the game, but he is always there cleaning up.

"He has been brilliant for us all season and he is a really good guy to have in the dressing room as well.

"Alex is always happy and putting smiles on everyone's faces  he is a massive part of the squad."

image.caption: CREATIVE ... Alex Song has weighed in with eight assists for Arsenal this season

pages.subdeck: SECRET WEAPON ... Rafa Nadal nicks Cristiano Ronaldo's new boots in new viral advert
pages.headline: ANYRON FOR TENNIS?
pages.teaser: CRISTIANO RONALDO is used to hitting the net - but for once, he has been doing his best to miss it as he filmed new Nike advert with Rafael Nadal. Watch the video here.
pages.articlebody:
CRISTIANO RONALDO is used to hitting the net  but for once, he has been doing his best to miss it.

The Real Madrid ace joined world No1 Rafael Nadal to play a unique tennis match for Nike's latest advert.

But while Nadal used his usual racket, Ronaldo donned his new boots to show off his silky footwork to take on the Spaniard.

The shocking pink Nike Mercurial Vapor VIII  built for their explosive speed  proved a smash hit for the former Manchester United star.

Ronaldo said: "Filming with Rafa is something different  me with football, him with tennis. It was a pleasure. I really enjoyed it."

The goal machine admits he is a big tennis fan and Real supporter Nadal is his favourite player.

He added: "I love tennis. Not just me but some of my family, like my brother who often travels with me.

"It's a sport I really like aside from football. "

Nadal, who has won 10 Grand Slam titles, said: "I am always watching football and could watch Ronaldo and his team-mates all day."

You can watch the pair in action in our brilliant video exclusively first with SunSport on our video player below.

Now you've seen the advert, you can now see the post-match interview where Nadal quizzes Ronaldo on his love for tennis.

pages.headline: City's sights on Modric
pages.teaser: ROBERTO MANCINI set alarm bells off at Spurs by admitting he would love to take Croatian
pages.articlebody:
ROBERTO MANCINI has set alarm bells ringing at Tottenham by admitting he is a big fan of midfielder Luka Modric.

The Croatian came desperately close to leaving White Hart Lane last summer when Chelsea were leading the charge.

Manchester City boss Mancini has revealed he views Modric, 26, as one of the top players in the Premier League.

But the Italian feels it will be hard to prise him away from the North London club.

Speaking on his 'pilgrimage' to Bosnia this week, Mancini said: "Luka Modric is an outstanding footballer, a great player.

"He is definitely one of the best in the Premier League.

"But it is by no means easy to get him because he plays for a big club, Tottenham. It is unlikely that they would let him leave.

"We are lucky to have another great player from these parts in Edin Dzeko.

"I have worked with quite a few players from these parts  not just Croatians, but Bosnians, Serbs and Montenegrins.

"I have many friends among them and I am very proud of it.

"They are really something special and they mostly play with invention and creativity."

Mancini admitted the trip to Medjugorje had given him a boost ahead of the last big push in the Premier League title race.

Now he is praying for a happy outcome and said: "You can really fill your batteries here.

"Millions of people come here and they leave as better people.

"Faith has helped me and helps me a lot in life. I cannot say that it helped me in my playing and coaching career because the Lord has more important things to do."

caption.#: Time we earnt our millions

pages.subdeck: FUMING ... Arsene Wenger has been banned for referee rant
pages.headline: Wenger kicked in to touch
pages.teaser: ARSENE WENGER will appeal his three-match UEFA touchline ban and £33,000 fine
pages.articlebody:
ARSENE WENGER will appeal his three-match UEFA touchline ban and £33,000 fine.

The Arsenal boss has been punished for improper conduct relating to comments made following the Gunners' Champions League second leg tie with AC Milan.

Wenger claimed referee Damir Skomina awarded too many free-kicks to the Italians, who progressed to the quarter-final stage with a 4-3 aggregate win.

He confronted the Slovenian official on the pitch after the final whistle and criticised him in his post-match comments.

Wenger said: "It is not justified and I will appeal straight away.

"I believe that they have transformed UEFA competition referees to be untouchable icons, where you cannot even have a word.

"The only thing they understand after the game is the report.

"I believe that when you have 25 years consecutively in Europe you can still ask the referee that you can have some discussion with him. It is very difficult to understand."

Wenger's ban will come into play next season should Arsenal qualify for the Champions League or Europa League.

UEFA handed him a one-match touchline ban for an on-field rant at referee Massimo Busacca following his team's last 16 exit to Barcelona last year.

The Frenchman was fuming at the Swiss referee's decision to send off Robin van Persie.

Wenger was then handed a further two-match touchline suspension in August for violating his Barcelona ban by communicating with the Arsenal bench from the stands during the play-off tie against Udinese.

Kicked into touch - Wenger hit with three-match Euro ban

pages.subdeck: SIDELINED ... Sergio Aguero
pages.headline: Aguero missing with mystery injury
pages.teaser: SERGIO AGUERO will miss Manchester City's clash with Sunderland on Saturday with a mystery injury
pages.articlebody:
SERGIO AGUERO will miss Manchester City's clash with Sunderland on Saturday with a mystery foot injury.

Blues boss Roberto Mancini revealed the Argy striker had a problem today but refused to explain what happened  merely labelling it as "stupid".

Aguero was sidelined for City's 1-1 draw with Stoke last weekend with a foot problem.

Mancini said: "It is a stupid injury.

"It was not his fault but he can't play with this injury  for one day, 10 days or two weeks. I don't know."

Mancini was repeatedly asked what Aguero had done but declined to elaborate each time.

He said: "I prefer not to say. But he couldn't play against Stoke and can't play tomorrow.

"I hope he can recover for Arsenal next weekend."

The Italian also revealed that Vincent Kompany is likely to return after a four-match absence with a calf problem, but Joleon Lescott remains sidelined with a hip injury.

pages.subdeck: D'OH ... Rio Ferdinand injured himself watching television
pages.headline: Top 10 stupid football injuries
pages.teaser: SUNSPORT runs the rule over the Top 10 stupidest injuries in football
pages.articlebody:
SERGIO AGUERO has fallen foul of a mystery injury  with boss Roberto Mancini describing it as "stupid".

So SunSport awaits with bated breath to see if the Manchester City striker's can be ranked among our favourites.

No10 - RIO FERDINAND

During his spell at Leeds, the England defender (above) managed to pick up a tendon strain in his knee watching television. Ferdinand had his foot up on a coffee table for a number of hours and ended up injuring a tendon behind his knee.

No9 - RICHARD WRIGHT

Missed Everton's FA Cup 4th-round replay at Chelsea in 2006 after falling over a notice warning him not to practise in the goalmouth.

No8 - EVER BANEGA

The Valencia midfielder broke his ankle when he was run over by his own car, having failed to properly apply the handbrake when he stopped for petrol.

No7 - ALAN WRIGHT

The vertically challenged defender strained a knee struggling to reach the accelerator on his new Ferrari.

No6 - DAVE BEASANT

The veteran keeper was KO'd for eight weeks in 1993 when he dropped a bottle of salad cream on his foot.

No5 - ALEX STEPNEY

In 1975 the Manchester United goalkeeper dislocated his jaw while shouting at his defenders during a match against Birmingham.

No4 - KIRK BROADFOOT

The Rangers defender suffered burns after an egg he had poached exploded in his face while he was inspecting it.

No3 - SANTIAGO CANIZARES

The Spain goalkeeper missed the 2002 World Cup after accidentally shattering a bottle of aftershave in his hotel sink. A piece of glass fell on his foot, severing a tendon in his big toe.

No2 - STEVE MORROW

Broke his collarbone after falling off Tony Adams' shoulders while celebrating Arsenal's 1993 League Cup final win against Sheffield Wednesday.

No1 - DARREN BARNARD

The former Barnsley midfielder tore a knee ligament after he slipped on his kitchen floor after stepping in a puddle of his puppy's urine in the 1990s.

pages.subdeck: CROCKED ... Stuart Broad
pages.headline: Broad ruled out of second Test
pages.teaser: FAST BOWLER to fly home from Sri Lanka immediately to have calf strain assessed
pages.articlebody:
STUART BROAD will fly home from Sri Lanka immediately after being ruled out of the second Test with a calf strain.

Broad played in England's first Test defeat in Galle despite struggling with a sprain to his left ankle in the build-up to the match.

He then suffered an injury to his right calf during the game and was in visible discomfort as he batted in the second innings.

England sent him for scans today and have opted to fly him home for rehabilitation.

More to follow...

article.caption: Spin or bust
Ton-up Trott but rest are rot!

image.caption: CROCKED ... Stuart Broad

pages.subdeck: TOP TARGET ... Angel Di Maria
pages.headline: Rom fancies £35m choice of an Angel
pages.teaser: BLUES owner Roman Abramovich targets Argy star to bolster attacking options
pages.articlebody:
CHELSEA are ready to splash £35million on Real Madrid's Angel Di Maria.

The Argentina winger, 24, is looking to double his current salary to £80,000 a week after turning down Real's renewed offer of £70,000.

And he is reportedly threatening to leave the La Liga giants at the end of the season unless they give him pay parity with some of his senior team-mates.

The news has put Europe's top clubs on red alert, with Roman Abramovich's Chelsea in the market for a world-class wideman.

Di Maria has represented Argentina at Under-20, Under-23 and senior levels  scoring five goals in 27 senior appearances.

He was snapped up by Portuguese side Benfica from Argentine side Rosaria Central in 2007, before moving to the Bernabeu in July 2010.

But he has proved something of a Jekyll and Hyde character and during a match against Levante earlier this season, his horror foul on Juanfran sparked a mass brawl.

AVB ditched me because I didn't sign new deal

pages.subdeck: IN FOR THE LONG HAUL ... Alex Ferguson
pages.headline: City ruled for three months, that's hardly a season
pages.teaser: OLD TRAFFORD chief says his players are the marathon men to Man City's sprinters
pages.articlebody:
ALEX FERGUSON says his players are the marathon men to Manchester City's sprinters.

City boss Roberto Mancini claimed his side deserve the title after 'dominating' the top of the table for so long.

But it is Ferguson and his Manchester United men who now lead the way by three points with just eight games remaining.

While Fergie acknowledges noisy neighbours City set the pace, he always had a long-term view.

He said: "They were playing great football in the first half of the season, there's no doubt about that. Everyone recognised that.

"We felt the brunt of it when they beat us 6-1.

"But a season lasts for a bit longer than three months."

Now United are top most have them down as favourites with their form and experience of these title situations.

Ferguson said last weekend that it was time for Mancini to feel the full wrath of squeaky-bum time after leading for so long.

Yet the Old Trafford chief received an unwelcome warning on Monday night to prove he is still not immune to the condition himself as United almost threw away two points at home to Fulham.

He said: "Well, when we started to give that ball away it nearly got it going."

United supporters may have ended the evening celebrating a vital 1-0 win at a crunch stage of the season.

But inside the home dressing room the atmosphere was very different.

Ferguson was furious with the way his team were losing possession in the closing moments of the game.

That was why he tore down to his technical area to gesticulate with his stars and start jabbing his watch to urge the final whistle. He said: "You have no idea the amount of work we do on possession in our training sessions.

"And then for a 10-minute period everyone on that pitch started giving the ball away!

"So I think my visibility is important at that time.

"I knew at that point that winning was the name of the game, because we were not going to score any more goals.

"We had a fantastic period after half-time actually when we didn't kill them off. The goalkeeper pulled off two fantastic saves and there was one blocked on the line. I thought at that point we were going to kill them off.

"And then you saw in that last 15 minutes anxiety crept in and we started giving the ball away.

"So it was a lesson in keeping possession of the ball which we are usually very good at it. But on Monday it let them down a wee bit."

The players knew the boss was not happy with their sloppiness and could sense a dressing-room hairdryer on the way.

Ferguson said: "I think some of them were trying to dodge to the other side of the ground!"

It was a sign to Fergie that even his side can be gripped with nerves in this mother of all title battles with their rivals.

He said: "Exactly, exactly. You just need to get over the finishing line.

"The players knew that a win would put us three points clear of City. It was an important day for us."

United could have blown it had referee Michael Oliver had a better view of Michael Carrick's challenge on Danny Murphy which should have led to a last-gasp Fulham penalty.

Ferguson admits they were fortunate to get away with it. He said: "From looking at the referee's position I can see why he didn't give a penalty kick when Danny Murphy was brought down.

"The ball has moved at an angle as Michael Carrick tackles him and from his position it wasn't clear, although it was a good claim."

United could be deposed at the top tomorrow on goal difference with City taking on Sunderland at the Etihad.

The Red Devils will immediately regain control with a draw or a win at Ewood Park on Monday when they take on Blackburn.

It is nip and tuck but Ferguson believes that the experience of his veterans could prove key.

He said: "I think the Ferdinands, Giggs and Scholes help that situation.

"If they were to lose their nerve, then we would be in trouble, but I don't expect that. I think they are well accustomed to it.

"Of course, we know football can turn round and bite you.

"That is the point we make about experience  hopefully that helps us. We have a small advantage, not a great advantage, but that can be changed in one game so we just have to take each game as it comes.

"That is the only thing I can do. The approach now is that once the Fulham game is over all the concentration is on Monday night at Blackburn.

"And after that the concentration will be on next Sunday's game against QPR. So that's the best way of handling it."

pages.subdeck: JUST THE JOB ... Harry Redknapp is perfect for England
pages.headline: Tel tells FA to 'Arry up
pages.teaser: FORMER Three Lions coach wants Redknapp installed before Euro 2012 bid is ruined
pages.articlebody:
TERRY VENABLES has urged the FA to get a move on and make Harry Redknapp England's new manager.

The SunSport columnist and former Three Lions boss fears we could pay a heavy price at Euro 2012, which starts 10 weeks today, if Wembley chiefs continue to drag their feet.

Tel said: "I think Harry is the candidate. But it seems to have gone on too long for me.

"There's now a double take and no one seems to know what's going on.

"What's good is the fact it looks to me like everyone wants Harry to take the England job. He's the popular vote."

The tournament in Poland and Ukraine starts on Friday June 8 with England's opening game against France on June 11.

Venables added: "The more time you can get in the better. There's nothing for you doing it cold.

"It's a big job and they have to get someone in there straight away to do something about it.

"I don't see any benefit in someone coming in at the last moment with a rah-rah-rah. He has to get to know those players."

article.caption: Nev fears for Lions' Euro chances
Now Stu's acting like he's got the job!
Pearce catches Olympic fever
El Tel returns to Wembley
England on tour

image.caption: JUST THE JOB ... Harry Redknapp is perfect for England

pages.subdeck: DO YA BEST ... Toure is demanding more from City's high-earners
pages.headline: Time we earnt our millions
pages.teaser: MIDFIELD star says wealthy but wobbling City can't afford to end the season with nothing
pages.articlebody:
YAYA TOURE has told his tottering Manchester City team-mates: It's time to justify the mega-millions Sheikh Mansour has spent on you.

Super-rich City have slumped from the top of the pile to three points behind arch-rivals Manchester United with just eight games to go.

And the inspirational Etihad midfielder insists such a star-studded squad finishing the season without any silverware will be viewed as a massive failure.

Toure admitted: "There are big expectations of us because we are now one of the biggest clubs in the world. We have spent a lot of money on players and we have a fantastic squad. Now we have to justify that and get the results we need to deliver the title.

"Because of the money everyone has been expecting us to succeed. That will be very tough now.

"But I have lost everything else this season  the African Cup of Nations, Champions League, the Europa League, FA Cup and Carling Cup.

"I don't want to lose the Premier League, too, so I will fight until the finish."

And Toure believes his team-mates will also rise to the challenge.

The Ivory Coast star added: "Players like Sergio Aguero, David Silva and Mario Balotelli have come here with me to City for one thing.

"Not for money  but to win games and win trophies.

"And I hope this year we will take the Premier League because it is the last step we have to take. I still think and believe we can do it this year but we must also remember this is one of the best championships in the world so it is very difficult to win.

"The competition here is unbelievable. That's why people all around the world love the Premier League  you never know if United, City or Chelsea are going to win and that's great." City can return to the top tomorrow if they beat Sunderland at Eastlands  but only briefly as United play at Blackburn on Monday night.

So Toure knows the big Manchester derby showdown at City on April 30 could be crucial to the destination of the Premier League trophy.

He added: "We know Manchester United are a fantastically strong team with fantastic experience  more than any other team  so it will be very, very tough.

"They are incredible. United are not the type of team who you can give anything to. When they are first they usually stay like that until the finish.

"And when you look at their programme they have easier games than us. Maybe their only difficult game is away to us. So we know it will be hard.

"That's why we need to concentrate and stay focused. That's why we must fight until the finish."

Toure reckons City have an ace up their sleeve with Carlos Tevez returning. He said: "If we win the Premier League this year it would be amazing for the club and the fans.

And with Carlos back everything can be nice."

And Toure is drawing on his experience of winning the title with Barcelona as he attempts to add another championship to his CV.

It would be a glorious finale to a frustrating season so far in terms of silverware.

He added: "When you go to a final, finals are for winning so I was really disappointed.

"What we did at Barca was a perfect example of what we need to do now. The thing at the Nou Camp was that we had known each other for two years.

"We played together for two years and in the second year we won everything, picking up six cups.

"We were strong together. This time of year will be tough for City but we are out of the other trophies and now we will be getting more rest. At Barca we managed to get Xavi, Iniesta and Messi all fit and that made everything easier.

"With City, Aguero missed the Stoke game with a little injury but he will be fit for Sunderland.

"Hopefully we can get everyone fit and take it game by game.

"We know it will be hard because United are a big club and have the experience of this.

"We need to concentrate and stay focused." Toure makes it clear City's multi-million pound signings need to be united to pip their neighbours to the title.

The midfielder added: "The most important thing is that we all go the same way now.

"Yes, you have to prepare your mind and yourself for disappointments. But also you must remember that we are in a great position and we can still do it."

But would you really put your money on it?

r.beasley@the-sun.co.uk

pages.subdeck: SWAN-TED MAN ... Swansea boss Brendan Rodgers is on Spurs' shortlist
pages.headline: Spurs eye Bren
pages.teaser: TOTTENHAM are set to move for Swansea's boss as they feel Redknapp will join 3 Lions
pages.articlebody:
TOTTENHAM are planning for life after Harry Redknapp and preparing a move for Swansea boss Brendan Rodgers.

Chairman Daniel Levy accepts Redknapp will take the England job when it is offered.

And Levy is a major fan of Rodgers, who is seen as one of the rising stars in European management after working wonders with the south Wales outfit.

And Tottenham are likely to sound out Rodgers, 39, even though he has just signed a new deal at Swansea.

Real Madrid chief Jose Mourinho would be too expensive and would not be provided with the player budget he demands.

Everton chief David Moyes and former Spurs hero Jurgen Klinsmann have also been on the list to take over.

Yet White Hart Lane supremo Levy believes he would face a major task to persuade Klinsmann to quit his job as United States coach while the family home is also in California.

Moyes is highly-rated in North Lane but Levy prefers the Barcelona-style football which Rodgers has brought to Swansea.

Having worked under Mourinho at Chelsea, former Reading and Watford boss Rodgers helped Swansea to promotion in his first season and they are currently 10th in the Premier League.

Initially on a one-year rolling deal, Rodgers signed a new 3½-year contract but he would be unlikely to turn down an approach from the north London giants.

pages.subdeck: LUCKY LET-OFF... Michael Carrick escapes a penalty award for his clip on Danny Murphy
pages.headline: City are handing Fergie ammo
pages.teaser: SUNSPORT columnist says title rivals Man Utd are profiting from City's crass outbursts
pages.articlebody:
WELL, Alex Ferguson DID say he had a lot of ammo.

Ever since, he has been picking off Manchester City like Wild Bill Hickok.

Though City fans would probably look at him more as a 'sniper'.

The bottom line is City have shot themselves in the foot.

First there was Patrick Vieira's dig that the return of Paul Scholes was a sign of weakness, in that Manchester United had not been able to replace him.

Then, after Fulham were robbed of a penalty at Old Trafford last Monday, the Frenchman blundered in again by telling the BBC that clubs like United might benefit from refereeing decisions at home.

Having seen Ferguson's reaction to the Scholes barb  turning it on its head and claiming City were showing signs of desperation themselves in having to recall Carlos Tevez from 'five months' holiday'  Vieira would have been better advised to have put a sock in it.

City then got very prissy, banning the BBC reporter concerned and issuing an embarrassing, holier-than-thou statement complaining of a 'serious and cynical misrepresentation' of Vieira's words. Though not once denying that he HAD said them.

Anyway, surely it's Ferguson's job to fall out with the Beeb?

The stats reveal that United have conceded nine league penalties at home since the start of the 2006-2007 season, City just one more.

The sides with the least are Chelsea and Aston Villa (six) and Liverpool (seven).

Once again, it was manna from heaven for Ferguson.

While it's all starting to get a bit childish, with tit-for-tat claim and counter-claim, he did make the point that a City executive should not be commenting on referees.

The last thing City need is to present such an inviting target to the old master of trench warfare, an expert in destabilising the opposition and never more so than when there's a title at stake.

It has not been a good time for City, with many of their less one-eyed supporters fearing that they have already blown their first championship in more than 40 years.

Having once had a hefty lead at the top of the table, they now trail United by three points after dropping 13 in 13 games.

Once again, Roberto Mancini is under intense pressure  not helped by his latest training-ground run-in with the apparently unhinged Mario Balotelli.

Throw in a United record of 28 points from 30, the untimely absence from their defence of skipper Vincent Kompany and Spanish midfielder David Silva's equally untimely drop in form and it is no wonder City's nerves are playing up.

Not that we should have too much sympathy for them, since they probably started it all with the gloating 'Welcome to Manchester' hoardings when they signed Tevez, prompting Ferguson's 'noisy neighbours' response.

Various crass statements from former chief executive Garry Cook did not help, either.

Yet United are hardly wide-eyed innocents.

Stirrer-in-chief has been Rio Ferdinand, who replied to Vieira's latest gaffe by tweeting 'Why is Vieira so concerned with Man United . . . .2 comments in a week or so . . . c'mon maaaaaaan let it go!' This, though, was almost tame compared to Ferdinand's deliberate wind-up a few weeks ago when he said: "Walking round town, you see far more blue shirts than you probably would have seen over the last 10 years.

"Success somehow brings people out of the woodwork."

That would have been particularly galling to all those City fans who have followed the club through thick and thin, while United were churning out one title after another and adding fresh names to the Surrey branch of the United Supporters' Club.

And so it all goes on. City entertain Sunderland tomorrow, with United travelling to Blackburn on Monday.

If, as Ferguson suggested yesterday, refereeing decisions tend to even themselves out over a season, City fans can comfort themselves with one image.

The look on the United manager's face as he struggles to control the volcano if one goes the other way at Ewood Park.

Nev court short

GARY NEVILLE could be found in the early hours of Wednesday morning surrounded by a bevy of swooning football writers in the lounge of a Lisbon hotel.

The apparent love-in was only disturbed by one cynical old hack wandering by, muttering: "Ah, the king surrounded by his court."

Yesterday, TV pundit Neville refused to speak to journalists at the Soccerex forum in Manchester saying: "This has trouble written all over it".

He had just given a talk on, erm, 'Football and the media'...

That's crafty

CRAFTY Italians, Part Two.

There was a lot of praise for AC Milan's defending and how they prevented Barcelona playing on Wednesday.

But the real star was the San Siro groundsman after preparing the sort of heavy pitch that had Arsene Wenger complaining the night before Arsenal's 4-0 defeat.

The surface was not just stodgy and well-watered but the grass so long Pep Guardiola almost had to send out search parties for Messi, Xavi and Iniesta.

These players normally float over the ground.

But they not only failed to control the ball but keep their feet.

For a while, you thought they were just having an off-night. Then, as Alex Ferguson once advised, you looked under the pasta sauce.

The return at the Nou Camp should be more of a level playing field.

Don't Makh me laugh

ARSENAL will laugh all the way to the bank should they manage to offload £60,000-a-week Marouane Chamakh to Paris St Germain for £5million. You do, though, worry about the sanity of PSG boss Carlo Ancelotti.

article.caption: City ruled for three months, that's hardly a season

caption.#: Time we earnt our millions

pages.subdeck: ON STANDBY ... Carlos Tevez
pages.headline: Tevez in for Serg
pages.teaser: MAN CITY'S top scorer is out of Sunderland clash  paving way for Tev's return to first XI
pages.articlebody:
MANCHESTER CITY'S top scorer Sergio Aguero is out of tomorrow's match at home to Sunderland.

And that leaves the door open for Carlos Tevez to start his first game for City since September after his controversial strike action.

Aguero, who has 28 goals this season, missed the draw at Stoke last week with a foot injury.

City thought the striker would be fine but he was unable to train this week.

It is a major blow for City boss Roberto Mancini with his side now three points behind Manchester United at the top.

Now he is ready to turn to Tevez to help revive their title challenge.

pages.subdeck: FINGERED ... Luis Suarez says he and his team-mates must carry can for poor league form
pages.headline: We are all to blame for Kop's slump in form
pages.teaser: URUGUAYAN striker last night admitted the Liverpool players have ruined Prem campaign
pages.articlebody:
LUIS SUAREZ last night surveyed the wreckage of Liverpool's Premier League campaign and insisted: We've all messed up.

Although the Reds have won the Carling Cup and are due to face Everton in the FA Cup semi-finals, they have slumped to five defeats in their last six league games.

Their sole win in that disastrous run was a 3-0 home win over the Toffees, while they were booed off at Anfield after a 10th loss this term  against lowly Wigan  on Saturday.

Kenny Dalglish's misfiring men now trail fourth-placed Tottenham by 13 points with eight matches to go in a season that was supposed to end with a place in the Champions League.

And Suarez blames the last-ditch 2-1 upset against Arsenal at the start of their slump for their gloomy league run.

The Uruguay striker, 25, said: "The problem stems from that day.

"It was a key match and the defeat really affected us. If we had beaten the Gunners everything could have changed.

"Our goal this season was to win trophies and qualify for the Champions League.

"The first part is fulfilled but we have failed in our other dream. Nobody could have believed we would be beaten by QPR and Wigan.

"What's gone wrong? We have incredibly missed out in the last minutes of matches, we've been affected by injuries and cards.

"The squad is angry and we really want to win at Newcastle on Sunday.

"Our mission is to finish in the highest position possible and to fight for the FA Cup.

"To win two cups will be the best we can give to the fans who demanded that we play in Europe's top competition.

"But there is always pressure because Liverpool is obliged to win every game and be high up in the table."

Suarez will be looking to add to his tally of 12 goals for the season at the Sports Direct Arena this weekend.

But all the pressure will be on his £35million strike partner, Andy Carroll, who has hit just eight goals in 47 appearances since joining Liverpool from Newcastle.

Suarez, though, said: "This is going to be a special match for Andy. He needs to demonstrate his quality and I have no doubt he will.

"Andy is a big forward but the pressure is not easy to overcome as a rookie. I had the same experience when I joined Ajax and Liverpool.

"Andy is working very well in training. He's always scoring and I'd be very happy if he did so on Sunday, although I don't think he will celebrate if it happens.

"It won't be easy at Newcastle. Few people thought they would be fifth and in with a chance of the Europa League but they've merited their success.

"But we want to restore our pride after our run of defeats  and we must give some joy back to the fans."

For all his own trickery and magic in the penalty area, this has been a difficult first season in England for Suarez.

He has actually scored just seven league goals himself and, of course, there were those eight weeks on the sidelines following the Patrice Evra affair.

Suarez added: "Being absent for so long was the worst period of my career because I do not like watching from the stands.

"I prefer to forget all about it  and I won't speak about Evra.

"My job is to score goals and I admit I have not always fulfilled it this season.

"Last year I was marked less tightly and that helped but, since August, defenders have known my style and it has been more difficult to surprise them.

"I'll keep on fighting. I want more of those big moments celebrating with the fans.

"Winning the Carling Cup was very special and now, to beat Everton and make the FA Cup final, that would be magic.

"Wembley is a temple for any footballer to play a final and to clinch a trophy is something to remember for a lifetime."

I'm happy Andy's nervous

pages.subdeck: PURE DEFIANCE ... Jonathan Trott strokes a four through the covers on the way to his 112
pages.headline: Ton-up Trott but rest are rot!
pages.teaser: TROTT'S epic knock could not mask the problems facing England's tormented batsmen
pages.articlebody:
JONATHAN TROTT'S epic of concentration, patience and skill could not mask the problems facing England's tormented batsmen.

Trott scored 112 against Sri Lanka in Galle yesterday but it was not sufficient to prevent his side losing their fourth Test out of four this winter.

Those defeats have seen England trapped in a spinner's web in subcontinental conditions. None has even been extended into a fifth day.

If they lose the Second Test in Colombo next week, England will surrender their world No 1 ranking to South Africa.

It is the first crisis for head coach Andy Flower, who must decide whether the current group of batsmen will ever have the nous to succeed on turning pitches in Asia.

Captain Andrew Strauss will assess his plans when he returns home next month. He is likely to stay in his job. But this sequence of losses, and a personal record of one century in 48 Test innings, is applying plenty of pressure.

Strauss refused to be drawn on his future. That is fair enough. After all, this is a man with two Ashes triumphs in charge of the world's top team, though some tough decisions lie ahead.

He is due to play his 100th Test at the end of the summer and that could be the moment he decides to hang up his bat.

There was a time yesterday when Trott and Matt Prior were at the crease and England were dreaming of achieving their highest-ever fourth innings run chase of 340.

Yet after Prior was freakishly caught at short leg from a full-blooded sweep, the end was swift. England's final six wickets fell for 31 runs in 13.1 overs and they succumbed for 264.

At least England are consistent. Their last three Test losses have been by 72, 71 and now 75 runs.

There are major question-marks over Strauss, Kevin Pietersen, Ian Bell and whoever out of Ravi Bopara and Samit Patel is chosen as the sixth main batsman.

Bell has 116 runs in those four Tests, Pietersen a top score of 32 and Strauss a long sequence of modest scores.

Bopara's career has been bedevilled by inconsistency and self-doubt, while Patel scored two and nine on his debut.

They may well gorge themselves this summer against West Indies and South Africa. But can England afford to take them to India next winter when the diet will again be non-stop spin?

There are many who believe England's top six needs freshening up, with the introduction of a new face or two.

That would certainly remove any comfort zone complacency.

England have dropped one batsman this winter, with Eoin Morgan discarded from the present tour. But instead of elevating a bright young thing, England chose Bopara and Patel  two players who have been on the international scene for several years.

Strauss said: "I don't think you need to be a rocket scientist to work out where things have gone wrong this winter "We haven't put scores on the board and you won't win many Test matches that way.

"I thought we showed in the second innings here that we have a lot of technical skill against spin bowling. But we didn't apply ourselves properly in the first innings.

"Trott's innings was a huge exhibition of skill, technique and application and he didn't deserve to be on the losing side.

"We left ourselves with too much to do in the fourth innings, which was the result of mistakes earlier in the game both in the field and with the bat."

Resuming on 111-2, Pietersen was soon caught and then Bell was lbw sweeping.

Trott, who escaped on 62 when Rangana Herath spilled a return catch, and Prior produced the fifth-wicket partnership of 81 that took England within range.

Yet after Prior fell, Patel was caught at short extra cover and Trott's 266-ball vigil ended when he was held round the corner.

Graeme Swann was another victim of the ill-chosen sweep shot and James Anderson and Monty Panesar fell to successive deliveries.

Man of the Match left-armer Herath finished with 12 wickets but is not in the class of Pakistan's Saeed Ajmal.

It was Sri Lanka's first home Test win in almost two years.

Stuart Broad, who played having just recovered from an ankle injury, has now tweaked his right calf and is a doubt for the Second Test on Tuesday.

j.etheridge@the-sun.co.uk
