pages.subdeck: FUTURE'S ROSY ... Stuart Lancaster takes charge
pages.headline: Fearless
pages.teaser: LANCASTER insists his England team will be proud, fearless  and world champs
pages.articlebody:
STUART LANCASTER insists his England team will be proud, fearless  and world champions.

The Six Nations caretaker coach was yesterday handed the full-time role after leading the Red Rose to second place in the Championship.

The Yorkshireman so impressed RFU chiefs he beat off a galaxy of big-hitters to the job, including former South Africa boss Nick Mallett.

And yesterday Lancaster revealed his bold mission statement to restore the Red Rose to glory.

He said: "There are three things I want to bring to the England team.

"The first is pride in the shirt and our supporters, the second is a vision of how we'll win the World Cup in 2015 and the third is that we create a team who play without fear, a team confident in their ability and who are allowed to express themselves.

"The players buy into this. They were fantastic during the Six Nations and they know we face a massive challenge in South Africa this summer.

"To win the World Cup we must go to the southern hemisphere to compete and win, not to just make up the numbers.

"We did well during our two months together, but we're well aware that we have a hell of a lot still to do.

"There are 37 Tests to play before the first World Cup game on home soil, and that process begins with three huge internationals in South Africa in June.

"The words that describe how I feel right now, however, are honour and privilege.

"To be head coach of any national team is a massive honour, but to do the job at a time when the next World Cup is in your country is also a massive responsibility.

"But this job is not about me, it's about the England team and their connection with the English public.

"We have 3,000 clubs and schools who play, 82,000 people who come to Twickenham for every Test, and I'm told some 10 million watched our game against Ireland.

"No nation in the world gets behind their team better than England, and I want all of those people to feel part of this journey."

RFU chief executive Ian Ritchie announced Lancaster would be head coach until the end of January 2016.

He said: "We have been through a rigorous and global selection process and are confident that Stuart is the right person to lead England rugby forward into the 2015 Rugby World Cup.

"He has shown throughout the RBS Six Nations, and subsequently in both interview and other conversations, that he has the skills and vision needed to be England head coach.

"We appointed somebody who we felt would put us in the best place to be competitive to win the World Cup.

"It's going to be very tough, the next series of matches in the autumn are against some very good teams."

Ritchie also denied that it was a gamble to appoint a man with so little experience of Test rugby.

He added: "I don't see it as a gamble. Stuart was given this job on merit against very strong competition.

"He ticks all of the boxes that we need. We came back to the view that Stuart was the best candidate."

Ritchie also admitted it was a plus that Lancaster was English. He added: "It's a bonus almost rather than a factor. To get the best candidate for the job was what we wanted, nationality was irrelevant."

Twickenham chiefs were impressed with the way Lancaster rebuilt the image of English rugby following the World Cup shambles in New Zealand last autumn.

The campaign was a disaster on and off the pitch and spelt the end of the Martin Johnson era.

Lancaster was a wrongly-disallowed David Strettle try from drawing with Grand Slam kings Wales and possibly retaining the Six Nations title.

Lancaster, a former head of elite player development, saw off competition from experienced international coaches and big names including former South Africa bosses Mallett and Jake White and former Italy coach John Kirwan.

Mallett accepted his defeat with good grace. He said: "I would like to congratulate Stuart on his appointment.

"I am sure he will continue to build on the good work he has done with the team in the aftermath of a difficult World Cup."

Lancaster will now assemble his coaching team and already has forwards coach Graham Rowntree on board from the Six Nations.

His next target will be securing the signing of backs coach Andy Farrell, who still has two years remaining on his Saracens contract.

Farrell is certain to finish the season with Sarries, who are hunting a Premiership and Heineken Cup double, but the RFU will probably try to do a deal at the end of the season.

Rugby Players' Association chief Damian Hopley said: "I am absolutely thrilled for Stuart.

"We have all been thoroughly impressed by his professional approach, vision and dedication to achieving the best for English rugby.

"Stuart is tremendously popular with the players and quickly earned their respect and trust through his honesty, humility and strong work ethic."

pages.subdeck: BACK IN THE DAY ... Pete Sampras after winning his final Wimbledon trophy in 2000
pages.headline: Sampras: I hated Wimbledon grass
pages.teaser: AMERICAN legend admits dislike for All England Club courts despite dominating tournament
pages.articlebody:
PETE SAMPRAS admits he hated playing on the grass courts at Wimbledon  despite dominating the competition for nearly a decade.

Speaking to CNN's Pat Cash, The American legend revealed his dislike for the playing surface at the All England Club where he won a mammoth seven titles from 1993-2000.

Sampras, 40, said: "I didn't like grass at all. When I first went over there, I hated the Wimbledon surface.

"For the first two or three years, I struggled. I came out with a bad attitude and was such a mopey player at times. It felt like Wimbledon didn't connect with me.

"But I finally broke through when I made the semi-final one year and I went on to own the place."

With 14 Grand Slam titles to his name, Sampras is ranked alongside Rod Laver and Roger Federer as one of the greatest players to grace tennis.

And he believes Novak Djokovic could soon be joining him if he keeps up his stunning form that has seen the Serb win four out of the last five major tournaments.

Sampras said: "Djokovic and Rafa Nadal are getting close. They're on their way."

Click on the video below to hear more from Sampras on his extraordinary career as well as the American's very own on-court masterclass.

pages.subdeck: GOOD GORD ... Honda ace Shedden with SunSport's Chris Hockley
pages.headline: 'Nearly man' Flash is aiming to shine
pages.teaser: GORDON SHEDDEN is hoping this will be the year when he will finally shake off his tag as the Nearly Man of touring car racing.
pages.articlebody:
GORDON SHEDDEN is hoping this will be the year when he will finally shake off his tag as the Nearly Man of touring car racing.

The wiry Scot, known as Flash, finished third in the British Touring Car Championship in 2010 and second last year.

And he said: "I am desperately hoping the trend will continue and I can walk away with the main prize come the end of this season."

First he will have to beat the man who pipped him to the title last year  his Honda team-mate, triple champ Matt Neal.

But Shedden, who opens his 2012 campaign at Brands Hatch on Sunday, has the perfect tactic to do just that.

He grinned: "I've just got to go a little bit quicker!"

In an exclusive video interview with SunSport, Shedden also told how he expects a whole host of other BTCC rivals to "come at me from all angles".

But he said his new Civic turbo "looks absolutely mega" and added: "The guys in the team have been burning the midnight oil to get Matt and I in with a chance right from the off."

Full the full enlightenment from Flash, click on our great video.
